reviews.text:
Great venue. Saw the counterfeit stones. Brilliant. Works well as a music venue. Nice cafe and bar. Bar prices reasonable.
Seats comfy with good leg room. No bad seats.
Saw 'Think Floyd' this evening, it was fantastic. 😳 They were spot on and incredible musicians. Rosie one of the vocalist was outstanding. Can't wait to see them again! ☺
This is an excellent theatre.  Always loads of different things on. Great auditorium, great bar and café.  Parking. Good pantomime every year. A wide range of shows. Why not pay them a visit?

Nice well run little theatre with polite and efficient staff. There are a few parking spaces right outside theatre entrance with a couple of large car parks within easy walking distance. Old style seats a little uncomfortable by the end of a show with just about enough legroom for a tall person although they are tiered seats with uninterupted viewing from any of the rows. Small cafe with hot cold snacks, and also a drinks bar. Good access for wheelchairs.

Lovely local theatre with some fantastic shows and acts. I have visited this place many times to see bands, singers and shows. If you get here early for a matinee performance you can sit down and have something to eat as well. Highly recommended.

Not disabled friendly no ramps, Car park is large but has as many craters as the moon. And could seriously damage your car.
The tith barn is open very rarely and is staffed by volunteers .
There's a children's play site a short distance away I would suggest go there instead.
Very good well received
well worth a visit full of things even from my life time that my kids have never seen
Little museum with some lovely local knowledge well worth a look if your local.
I Agree with Mr David Guests review. It's a great pity that there isn't enough room to show everything to good effect.
Great cafe with National trust standard cakes and lunches. A community garden with bags of interest. Well done to the boil tests!
I was pleasantly surprised by Rainham Hall. It's garden grounds were larger than expected and it was all well tended and cared for.
Lovely place for my sister's baby shower, staff where very kind and helpful setting the place up

Charming house. Currently showing an exhibition about the time when the house was requisitioned in WW2 to be used as a nursery school for female munitions workers’ children. Nice tea room in the stable block, in the traditional NT manner. Easy parking at the station on a weekend.
Lovely Mother's day afternoon tea

Lovely place. It's a really nice park to ride a bicycle, especially in the summer the path takes you around a lake which is a great place to sit down and chill out. Its usually pretty quiet there and I really do recommend going from around the parking area near Travis Perkins all the way to Tesco at airfield way.

I love Hornchurch Country Park. Since they modernised the elm park end, there is a great play area for the kids (including an awesome spitfire) and a cafe that serves hot and cold foods.

You can have a lovely walk, run or cycle through the park and it's nice to be immersed in nature instead of concrete for a while.

Even on a freezing morning there is plenty to see here. Hoping the Wildlife Trust will develop the scrape by the visitor centre. Plenty of wildlife and plant life to see, if you have a keen eye. Trudge around with your head down won't do it. Good to see hundreds of new trees being planted by the Forestry Commission in Berrick Woods today.

Lovely large county park. Play area for small children. 
Wonderful RSPB area, woodland and lake. Great for running, cycling, hiking and dog walking. 
People are warm and friendly with a nice community feel. 
Couldn't recommend this park highly enough

A really nice country park. Multiple play areas for the children, a lovely new visitors centre and plenty of paths to trek or take your dog for a walk. Parking cam be a little tight, but they are in the process of extending the main parking area to increase capacity.
Good coffee, apple crumble cake not warm but hey ho excellent
Love this place a real gem in Hornchurch. Staff always welcoming and friendly the fresh bread and cakes are absolutely delicious
Lovely selection of items for lunch. Bread delicious and cakes too wonderful for words.

The first thing I'm delighted to say is that this fabulous patisserie is in the centre of my hometown of Hornchurch. Although we're not regular visitors over the thirteen years they've been open we have managed to pop in a few times a each year for either a coffee & cake or a light lunch. The patisserie is run by a lovely french family and it's their friendliness which really really brings the locals together. They serve the most delicious cakes & pastries as well as sandwiches , toasties , flatbreads etc. As we were in town on Saturday we decided to pop in and as usual the place was very busy. We ordered a coffee and then taking a look at all the amazing cakes I decided to try the Banoffee Tart which was absolute heaven. Owner Helene then came over for a chat and also to ask what I thought of the tart as it was new. She then pulled up a chair and we started to chat not only about the cakes but all things associated with the area. She then treated us to another of their amazing cakes a Lemon Meringue Tart which was so light and again a delight Another thing they specialise in is to make large cakes for special occasions and to which yesterday we was delighted to see a couple of stunning examples of this. The first was an amazing Elton Mess Cake and the second a heavenly Chocolate creation Before we left Helene decided to bring us another little treat. A small sample of the amazing Croquembouche and no surprise here either as this was a cake lovers dream I would definitely recommend a visit to Le Moulin. So if you're local and for some bizarre reason you haven't been then do so or if you happen to be in the area and looking for somewhere to have lunch then this place is a must stop. I'm looking forward to my next visit already and enjoy some more delights
EXCELLENT food friendly cosy atmosphere very welcoming
Adore Simply Blues.  Gorgeous food, great prices and excellent service.
Had a great night. But a big shame that it's going to be closing on the 30th of March I've been going to this restaurant for just over 29 years will sadly be missed
Great food and great menu with friendly staff will definitely go again.
Fantastic food, great atmosphere. Used to eat at Simply Blues in Leigh On Sea but it closed so thought we would give Hornchurch a try. Wasn't disappointed.
Always great food and service. I have been going there for almost 20 years and never had a bad meal. They could update the menu a bit but then why mess with perfection

A visibly vibrant place and good seating arrangement but the food quality doesn't match the expectation. Serving portion is less. Menu needs revamp to suit locale cuisine and portion size should increase.

We are new to Chandigarh.... We heard many things about elanta mall so we went there and must say very good mall... Have been to Nando's.. The menu was unique and tasty... Compare to price the quantity was not upto the mark but quality was good... Ambience is  also attractive.. Staff is also very cooperative and friendly... Non veg menu was also good... Here u can get alcoholic and non Alcoholic both the drinks.. So go for it..

Loved the food they served, so happy to visit this place. Had the brand dinner tonight with delicious food. It's a great place to eat and enjoy with your friends and family. They serve alcohols too, so don't worry about it.

Been here a few times whilst visiting Chandigarh. I compare to Nandos in the UK and on that basis it gets a 5 star. 

Food comes out fast and staff are attentive. 

Food quality is same as UK. If ordering normal burger, wings or similar then you can't go wrong. 

The main reason for not giving 5 stars would be some of the promotional food or special menu items miss the mark.
By far the best Mexican I've had in the city. The service was good. The staff was nice. And they seemed to care about what matters to me as a customer. So, bonus points for that.
Very nice staff and the food was excellent. Didn't take long to arrive and was hot and fresh. Pretty consistent ordering at Pizza Express. There is a takeaway option also if you need to dash.
Very good pizza. Perfect service. I will come back for sure ;).
Such good food! At first it looks like a fast food restaurant but the food is really good quality and tasty!
Good pizza, slow service.
Delicious food. Friendly, helpful staff.
Had family celebratory for nine people. Very good food, service and atmosphere. Wouldn't  hesitate to recommend.
Nice menu choice including vegetarian and kids.   Three course meal for 4 adults and 2 kids plus bottle of wine came to just £85 when using compare the meerkat discount.
First visit, very posh, staff friendly and welcoming.  Had risotto with salmon & king prawn.  Cooked to perfection and very tasty.  Will go back.
Had a great birthday celebrating 🎂 food and atmosphere really good
Good food, nice atmosphere, reasonable price.

This place is a little hard to find but GPS will get you there.   This place is beautiful,  it shows management that cares.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating, and the food was amazing.   The prices are comparable to other local Indian restaurants, but I would consider this upscale dining.   New favorite place!

Ever been to an Indian restaurant and think, "I'm not sure how much of this I'll like.". This is NOT that kind of place.
  The interior design is amazing.
   The food is amazing.
    The price is amazing.
 This place will certainly be in business for a LONG time, but do yourself a favor and stop here ASAP!

I used to enjoy this restaurant but I had not been there for years. We went back yesterday afternoon for lunch and unfortunately it was disappointing. We opted not to have the buffet, rather we ordered from the menu, and maybe that was the issue? It seems we were ignored. It took a long time to get our drinks. When our food arrived, it was cold. I had asked for a spice level of spicy, and there was no spice whatsoever.  After our meal we sat for about 20 minutes and no one acknowledged us. My fiance had to walk up to the register, which was also empty, and wait for someone to return so we could ask for boxes. After we were given boxes we sat for yet another 10 minutes and did not receive our check so eventually we had to go back to the register and wait AGAIN. I understand that they have to keep up with the buffet since it's a large draw, but if tending to the buffet causes them to ignore other paying customers and offer cold food then perhaps they should not even have the option to order off of the menu and do a buffet only. I will stick with the other Indian restaurant that I frequent that has hot food and more prompt service.
We have had Indian Food all over America and this was definitely one of the best Indian Restaurants we’ve been too. The food was delicious and so fresh.
One of my favorite Indian places to eat at for lunch with some coworkers. They changed the layout recently and seems like the food is being cooked by a different chef but overall still good.

Great, cheap home made Indian food.
I went on a Sunday morning, which is when they have their buffet, so I can't comment on serving sizes. However there were plenty of options and everything I tried (about six different items) was very tasty.
Also, the price is unbeatable at only ten pounds.
The staff were friendly and very attentive, warning me when a couple dishes that had run out were replenished.
The atmosphere was quiet at the time I went (around 2.30, so maybe a bit late for lunch in England), which I didn't mind at all.
If it had been open for lunch on Moni would have gone again before catching my flight in the afternoon.

Have read mixed reviews on this place, but glad I went and tried it myself. Ordered the butter chicken and was honestly some of the best I’ve had. Portions were very generous and great value for money. Definitely worth the visit.
Waou, great restaurant, food was delicious, service discreet (was a quiet evening) and affordable price. Recommended

Great atmosphere and cheap prices. I felt like i was eating at a really fancy restaurant. The waiters were friendly and knowledgeable about allergies, gluten free, dairy free, vegetarian etc. The wet towelettes at the end of dinner were a very nice touch. I will be visiting again

I am staying in hotel royal London. Which is just few yards away from that. First of all they are not even  Indian they are Bangladeshi. They are just using Indian name. I ordered Lamb bhuna, dal tadka,keema naan and tandoori roti. It was a disaster  for me. They just boiled the lamb in pressure cooker. They burn our daal. They were not even near the Indian food.

Love walking into a Starbucks and smelling the fresh coffee. This location was clean and the staff friendly. Coffee was made to order and correctly made for this picky coffee drinker lol. This spot has an area for when you are wanting to socialize or break out the computer/books and do some studying while sipping on a latte. Only problem I seen was the drive through and parking area are very tight but couldn't take a star away just for that. Keep it up at this location cause my little girl and I will definitely be back for our coffee.
Always fast, friendly, and informative! Their coffee is great and their snacks are always yummy! Mobile pickup through their app is always very convenient as well!

Yummy but prices need to stop going up, they  are beyond being a very successful business that has millions of people addicted and stopping for ine of their many yummy beverages and foods almost every day like its crack, stop being greedy with the cost increase of everything, PLEASE. I want to be able to afford my coffee "crack" lol just playing, kinda. Attention there's no illegal drugs served at any Starbucks facility
... that I'm aware of!
Very friendly service. Got the order correct. Fast.
Rude, impersonal staff, slow service, dirty restrooms. The food is blah, you get better quality food at much lower prices at McDonalds or any of the other fast food chains in the area.
The sandwich was a mess when i opened it up. Sauce was spilling out.
Good food, good service, good price

New management has done an amazing job taking this location to the next level.  Service is top notch and the food quality has improved exponentially!  Speed of service is noticably faster.  Definitely will be having more quick lunches here in the near future!
Agree! Food quality has gotten so much better since the old owner sold it.
Very friendly/polite staff!

Very popular place must visit 
5 Star experience in Buckingham Palace. We booked the Buckingham Palace tour months ago so we could see it over the Holiday break. They only offer this tour for a few weeks in the summer and winter when the Royal family is out of town. All I can say was it was worth every penny. The tour feels very exclusive. You enter through the side of the palace, check your coat, and meet up with your tour guides. 3 guides take ~20 people through the palace explaining the rooms, the history, and the artifacts / art within. It was breathtaking and probably the best thing we did while in London. The tour was ~2 hours and at the end they offered us all Champagne and 20% off in the gift store. Its not a cheap tour at ~90 pounds but I felt we got our money worth and saw something few people get to see. Also in the end they walk you out in groups of 6 out the front door of the palace in front of everyone outside the palace gates. A nice touch to end a magnificent experience.

It's a bit crowded even in winter but nonetheless a great experience seeing the change of guard! The snow makes it feel epic. I recommend arriving at least 20min before it begins to secure a good spot.

Visiting London and not visiting Buckingham Palace would be really unfair. This is a 300+ years old Heritage Palace where the Queen of England currently stays and this is the headquarter of Her Majesty. This is  also in the city of Westminster and hence if you visit the city of Westminster, you can see Buckingham Palace, Big Ben and Parliament of UK all three tourist attractions. We were lucky enough to see the change of guard duty from outside, however, we did not have the registration to see the Buckingham palace from inside ( you need to do the registration earlier for this limited/restricted visit inside the palace).

A must stop on a tour of London! Ive been here a few times showing friends & family but this time we happened  upon the Changing of the Guards, it's one of those experiences that I believe is worth seeing. It's only a 20 min stroll along a very pretty park to Big Ben & London Eye. Using the London Underground is great to get around, but honestly, so much of London is within walking distance, one place just easily leads to another.

5 Star experience in Buckingham Palace.  We booked the Buckingham Palace tour months ago so we could see it over the Holiday break.  They only offer this tour for a few weeks in the summer and winter when the Royal family is out of town.  All I can say was it was worth every penny.

The tour feels very exclusive.  You enter through the side of the palace, check your coat, and meet up with your tour guides.  3 guides take ~20 people through the palace explaining the rooms, the history, and the artifacts / art within.  It was breathtaking and probably the best thing we did while in London.  The tour was ~2 hours and at the end they offered us all Champagne and 20% off in the gift store.

Its not a cheap tour at ~90 pounds but I felt we got our money worth and saw something few people get to see.  Also in the end they walk you out in groups of 6 out the front door of the palace in front of everyone outside the palace gates.  A nice touch to end a magnificent experience. :)
Situated in the heart of city.Awesome place to hangout with friends. Friends can sit together for long time . Burgers are awesome in taste. All food items are good in taste.
Love to come here, after my coaching classes. It is very nice place for sitting with friends
Well !!!! Who doesn’t know abt Mcdonald 😄❤️ and i think 90% foodies will prefer to take a quick hunger break here. I request those 10% to fill the gap sooner the better 🔥 🔥🔥

It is situated in the Atlantis mall Civil lines......Prayagraj...... 
You all are well aware of the fact that it is a place mostly crowded.... it promotes self service.... the menu is being displayed on the screen above counters.... very limited items are there in this mcD Allahabad...  but it will be freshly prepared and served hot.... drinking water is available for free but one have to ask for it..... its affordable...... one cannot have a cosy atmosphere or a silent atmosphere since its generally over crowded....

I recommend you to taste ice creams...

I would prefer KFC for burgers. But if u want something lite than you ho for it.
The place is always crowded. Try the mcflurry and allu ticki

I go into Burger King on Wednesday because I meet up with a friend. We are at least in Burger King 3 times a month we usually have ice tea. But once in awhile will have something to eat. It's always clean and so are the bathrooms. Which I have to say I love the up-to-date look in Burger King. I especially like the way they designed the bathrooms. I like knowing I have privacy when I go into the bathroom.  Its become our favorite spot to catch up.
I really love their whoppers and their fries. I ordered a 10 piece chicken nuggets for a reasonable price. Always love Burger King anywhere I go and definitely recommend this place.
Usually really fast service, except during lunch hour. Great customer service as well
Had a bacon csburger, the hamburger was the size of a 50ct. Coin with 1 slice of bacon, the top of the bun was bigger than the meal.. very small hamburger, never again. Half star for the French fries
Very Clean and great service.  Awesome people. I felt welcomed.
Excellent service and reasonable prices. Lunch around 7 pound. One of our party had a peanut allergy, advice and due diligence by management was second to none. Would recommend.

The classic chicken burger is an absolute legend. The chicken is cooked to a point of perfection. The meat was tender, juicy and delicious. It’s even better when you order the bottomless drinks as they come in different flavours for £2.75 each. I would suggest try the Strawberry Mojito with the burger it’s really tasty. Full of flavours. The staff was friendly as we asked for about 5 rounds of bottomless drinks as they were really kind serving us multiple times. Would recommend this place with a large group of family and friends. Nice spot for a date night too.
I had the burger option without the bun (bread) and it tasted wonderful. Wasn't too busy. Great place.

Best burger chain In London, it's always consistent in delivering a great meal. Top picks are the truffle cheese fries, hot diggity burger, and a chocolate milkshake. The specials are always amazing, bring back the Ruby Murray and the Arnie sarnie! Make sure to get the app on your phone and to use your friend code to get freebies when you first join, if anyone needs a code they're welcome to use mine (gldsG) to get a free side ;) 
The best deal I've had was the "free burger when you spend over £7", me and a friend both bought two burgers and turned them into quad stacks! The images attached are my friend trying his best to tackle a taxi driver and hot diggity combined, it was incredible, as expected!

Lovely burgers cooked to the point of your choice. Very good quality ingredients and juicy beef. There's not much else you can ask for from a burger place. The fries where crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. They serve some fizzy drinks with free refills. I also really liked the vibe of the place: cozy and staff is super friendly. I would love to visit again.

When you want a delicious fresh made to order burger this is the place to go.  Great burgers ,fresh buns , and many delicious  toppings.  Food is  consistantly good and service is fast and friendly. I like when you order fries they don't skimp on the amount and always throw  extra into the bag.  Fries are cut fresh and delicious.  Clean restaurant with nice seating.  Free peanuts to munch on while you wait.  Food is delicious .  Love it.

This Five Guys was amazing. I was able to order online so I only waited a few minutes.  They gave me a free soft drink while I waited.  I received an amazing burger, plenty of perfect very hot fries.  Clean, quick and awesome service.

Always a good experience. Staff is pleasant (and they were even singing along to the music, which was fun) and the restaurant is always clean. Coke machine was out of quite a few flavor cartridges, but this was the first time that happened.

The food is good but I always thought it is expensive for what you get. 
We got 2 small cokes, small French fries, 1 bacon cheese burger (double patty) and 1 cheese burger (single) .... All for the bargain price of $27.30! Plus a wonderfully cozy atmosphere.
This place was always so clean & staff was so friendly. Anyone else notice the un-cleanliness or the attitudes between the pm manger & staff :(  we will not be returning!

One of the best Pizza Huts in the area. First folks in so the buffet wasn’t completely out yet. Though the food that was, was absolutely delicious & hot. Staff was friendly & on top of things. Restaurant was pretty clean & well organized.
SO so ummy...and I love supporting young readers -- thanks, Hut! ...did I mention how very yummy the pizza was? Seriously. Good pizza 🥰
Love their pizza! It's the best anywhere. The service at this one is amazing, too!
Food was good and so was the service. Waitress was great also!
Pizza hut has been always the best pizza and love the salads and sauces. Great services as well.

One of my favourite places to visit regularly. Lots of free exhibitions as well as paid for viewings. There's 4 art shops across both the main buildings, stocking prints, books, T-shirts, bags art equipment etc. Great for gift ideas.  As a member there's a choice of two members rooms, which tend to be a lot less crowded than the other restaurants and cafe's available. There's also two balconies available in the original members room with fantastic views. 
A great day out and meeting place. Couples, families or viewing alone you can't fail to enjoy it.

Really nice Gallery! Is amazing the way it works. Love the great open spaces in here. Is amazing to visit at any time. Love late evening as it is quiet and the lights are really nice. Great location as it sits just in South bank :)

Great free Art Gallery where they also host amazing events for young people to engage and a chance to be creative. If you're in the area its worth a visit, if not dedicate a whole day to it as you will not have enough time to finish the whole gallery. They host many art talks and workshops, and the exhibitions they put on are always well thought out and worth a visit.

Beautiful gallery situated inside a refurbish electric central. The presentation of every artwork includes suggestions for further reflection upon it. However if modern and contemporary art are not your cup of tea might not be the best place

A fancy museum with a lot of various artwork and styles, sometimes leaving you with the "huh?" factor, but in the end, it is worth the trip, though it is a bit out of the way from the center, but being close to the Tower Bridge makes it worth going this direction and stopping by the Tate, I was a walker, so I didn't take any transportation! 

Most of the exhibitions are free, but of course the most fancy ones are ticketed, so bring some loot, the gift shop is also a nice place to shop by!

Lovely park to bring children to especially the water fountain area. Really busy and nice vibes during summer with lots of families and children. Can also take time out for yourself to enjoy the greenery and people watch, sitting on the park chairs and taking in some ⛅ shine. I enjoyed it a lot last summer.

Nice small place near British museum. It became my favourite small area because here you are able to sit around a small water fountain in silence with other people and just observe the birds while thinking about whatever is going on for you at the moment. I suppose everyone has a place and this one is mine.

Nice park in the centre of London, right in the heart of the buzz of the city but a nice area of calm.  This park has lots of benches, so a good place to stop and eat lunch or even have a picnic on the grass on a sunny day.  Always something going on round here, and one of my favourite places in London for people watching!

It was a beautiful day for the time of year and it felt like spring even though it was the middle of February! I chatted with two people who also sat on the same bench to enjoy their lunch. The park is a pleasant sojourn between  the Tate modern and other London  museums. As well as many benches to sit on this park also has a cafe just inside the gate. A toilet and telephone boxes just outside and close to Russell Square underground station. A memorable part of my short trip back to London from Malaysia after 21 years!

very important historical area which is the origin of the Russell group which is a bit like the American ivy league there is a coffee place in the park and every morning at around 7 a guy who feeds the pigeons and is then covered by the pigeons. the Russell square is directly across from the Russell hotel which is now been renamed the Fitzroy and that's where all the universities were forced to meet during world war II. you should look for lucky George which is a dragon in the hotel which is one of a pair the other one being on the Titanic which is in a slightly less accessible location . also the square is good for jogging in the morning if you don't mind going around in a circle.

I was here on vacation and it was my first spot! I knew it had to be a wonderful museum it is a huge place! As you walk in, you will see an amazing lobby with so much walking space, compared to NYC museums, it gets crowded, but the amount of space you have makes it very relaxing, the exhibits were amazing and Egypt was the top of my list. The halls and other exhibits are very creative. 

The collections they have here are one of a kind, as I am use to only seeing a long amount of artwork in NYC, I find this a treat to see such creative pieces and amazing history. I would recommend this place for anyone! Plus it is donation only, so you won't burn a hole in your pocket.

Absolutely huge... Good displays and decent organization progressing through time frames and regions. If you wish to actually read information about each piece, you'll be there for a week! They have so many things with a satisfactory extent of related information for the average history enthusiast. I could easily spend multiple days here. Plus, the only cost is a suggested donation.

Better than The Louvre. Not such a maze. Great displays and exhibits. Ultra friendly staff everywhere ready to help and explain. Easy to get around and see most of it in one full day, however you may need 2 or 3 days to really see it all and take it all in. Entry is free but there is a donation box. Accessible bathrooms at regular intervals and cafes available and easy to find. Must see museum that's not torture to explore.

I enjoyed going through the Assyrian section of the museum! I found the pieces were well preserved and brilliant to behold. At the time I was on a trip to Israel so it was interesting to see the stele of Sennacherib. I enjoy the vastness of the collections at the museum. And I would recommend setting aside several days to enjoy the museum in its entirety. Also bring some comfortable shoes because there is so much to see.

This is a must see museum for any visit to London. It's one of the great museums of the world and is free to the public, though a so-called donation is strongly and not subtly encouraged. The collections of Greek antiquities are exceptional, but every exhibit is worth seeing. The majestic modern atrium is breathtaking. A best kept secret is the less crowded cafe on the first floor for a sit down and refreshments.

This is one of the best of the smaller museums in London. It tells the story of the Foundling Hospital, and the foundlings who were brought up in the Hospital. The Hospital also was the first art gallery in London and has a good collection of art. They also host modern art exhibits and usually have small temporary exhibitions that are fascinating. A visit here can easily be combined with the nearby  excellent Dickens Museum in Doughty Street which has a nice cafe.  Highly recommended. Good for families as well...

This is a thought-provoking museum. It tells many heartbreaking stories that help you to cherish what you have now.
But it also has a lot of great and positive collections to let people know about its history and the past of London.
This museum need some entry fees, but it is really worth to visit!

Lots of paintings of the ‘great and good’ when I’d rather have seen more about the foundlings themselves. Overall, I was rather disappointed. The grand meeting room and its opulence says it all really. Having said all that, Coram’s ceaseless work in founding it was a fantastic achievement.

Lovely place to go as they have a free tour you can join and be shown around and taught some very interesting history about this museum. Beautiful paintings as well as entrancing stories that pull you in! A must go for museum fanatics like me!
A little gem of a museum with a truly fascinating tale of two parts to tell: one part social history and one part art. Genuinely enthusiastic staff. 90 minutes very well spent.

Small but really interesting museum if you're interested in Egyptian history with super nice staff. There are a lot of items (more than you might inside in such a small museum and maybe it could be a little better curated), but many of the pieces are in really excellent condition (better than other world class museums) and there's a nice short guide that you're given that highlights a few of the hallmark pieces. Great to kill an hour or so.
amazing so much in such a small museum. very friendly staff. If you are visiting the British museum make sure you visit the Petri.
Mummified mice, bead dresses and other rarities await you at this prolific Egyptian university collection at UCL.
I discovered this museum too late. I really loved it,probably one of my favourite one in London. So interesting and useful. Amazing.

As a visitor to London from the USA, I really appreciate the not only the historic materials housed here but the museum itself with the Victorian-era sensibility was so charming. This is not an overwhelming museum to absorb.

I stayed here for two years 2016-2018. The College is extremely supportive and I was lucky enough in my first year to meet the Queen. As a musician, we had a few practise rooms. The pianos won't be as well-maintained compared to the ones at the conservatoires, which is expected. Musicians were also all very encouraged to host concerts. I really enjoyed my time here and it's sad to leave :'(. 

Come! : )

I have lived there for a year as a postgraduate student.  When investigating it, I looked at google reviews, so I thought I'd give back.  There were  some hesitations I saw on a couple.  Honestly, they baffle me now.  The facilities are excellent, especially in William Goodenough House where I stay.  The community is warm and vibrant.  The events are constant, varying from "Port Talks" on various subjects, to student concerts, to trips throughout England and even three a year to continental Europe (for those selected, there is an application process).  I went to Venice on an opera trip.  But that's a small point compared to the year round facilities and atmosphere.  And location!  Amazing place to be be, in the center of London, on a quiet beautiful square.  Also, whoever was criticizing the wifi: never had a problem.  Work great.  Come!
It’s not the best college but it’s Good Enough...

A beautiful events venue besides a postgraduate residence open to students from any university or college. An absolutely quite library with mainly fiction with visitor entry less than an hour.. Very receptive people.

I am a current resident here. The facilities are very good and the staff generally efficient, although always behaving too formally to be called friendly. They take in a lot of US students and Canadian students, as well as people from the richer Commonwealth. So this is not the most culturally diverse experience, as there aren't that many British, Europeans, and poorer-Commonwealth and developing countries people staying here. There are a lot of activities, but many are formal (you really need a suit to go to many of the events here). Like the a commenter who disliked it on Yelp said the place is full of people 'who like to dress like their fathers'. They have a Chaplain rather than a secular psychologist to offer 'counselling'. The ethos is still very much stuck in a British Empire mentality. Also from my own personal experience living in an all male corridor there is also quite a bit of public macho behaviour going around (last pearl I heard was: A: 'I'm staying in London for Xmas'; B: 'For a girl?'; A: 'Nah man, I would NEVER do that for a girl'). Many of the neighbours here don't even say hi when they meet each other on the corridor or the street, and just blank whoever they don't think is cool enough or part of the in-crowd in my corridor. So this place offers frequent encounters with people who are self-centered/individualistic, passive-aggressive, and have an inflated sense of self-importance. If you don't care about that  / are unfazed by idiotic behaviour and just want a place with excellent facilities to live in close to uni then Goodenough does offer that.

To BBC senior editors, 

We are the big community of BBC audience in Afghanistan. Since many years, we have inherited listening to the BBC from our father’s generation. Not to be unsaid that today we have so many reliable national and international media outlets that broadcast in our national languages, where we can get our daily feeds from. BBC is one of these reliable outlets. The BBC Afghan editors’ recent decision to change the name of its official Facebook page to (BBC Dari) is an absolute insult to BBC’s Persian-Dari speakers and an approach seen as stirring up ethnic and language divisions in the country. FYI: there is no language as Dari and it is only a Persian dialect. As we do understand the BBC’s strict policies don’t allow the company to get involved in a country’s ethnic dispute, we respectfully ask the channel to refrain from this at a situation of fragility and adversity in Afghanistan. We as responsible audience respectfully ask the senior managers to urgently stop such a provocative approach and respect your millions of audience who speak this language in Afghanistan. Whilst we will wait for the BBC’s urgent action, some of the audience have already started unliking your page as a sign of protest. More actions will follow. Please don’t let the BBC be seen as attempting to escalate ethnic and language disputes in the country. 

Regards 

A Persian speaking audience from Afghanistan

#unlike_bbc_dari

Not a huge selection of merchandise, and quite expensive. But there is an amazing view of the 24hr newsroom and you can watch live weather reports from the window. The BBC have stopped running tours now, so this view is as close as you can get to seeing inside.
To enter you need to be accompanied by  someone who work here.
Told by a security guard the shop no longer exists.
Tell the security you want to go to the shop and then watch the people working in the newsroom.

I've been here a few times and have impressed every time. The prices are unbelievably good. The food is all vegetarian or vegan and all delicious. There is usually not much space to sit but you can take away and you get 20p off if you take your own containers. It's a very cozy place and the food is really delicious and healthy. You get big portions, especially of the side salads, of which there is a lot of choice. The bread rolls are fresh baked and so good! The drinks are all quite fancy and not as affordable as the food unfortunately. You don't get table service here, it's like a canteen where you queue, get your food straight away, and go sit down with it. This is good for if you go on your lunch break as it's really quick to get your food.
Great little place. Fantastic veggie/vegan food at a very reasonable price. Very friendly staff. Relaxed cafe seating area. Original dishes.

If you have an allergy don't bother going here. The staff behind the counter are not helpful and very rude if you have any questions.
Also the food I did get was drenched in oil which made it impossible to eat, and any health benefits from the vegetables was taken away with the amount of oil. 

If you don't have an allergy and like greasy food then I'm sure this place is fine as everyone else seemed happy with their food, they had the soup.
Lovely healthy food ,vegan,vegetarian, great cakes and friendly atmosphere
Lovely place with friendly staff. Food was amazing!

Imaginative dishes - quail as a starter for example - which were well presented and tasty. Everything was going swimmingly until I saw the bill: £35 for two courses and a beer, which alone cost £6.50. So even though the restaurant has a nice atmosphere and the staff were excellent it only gets 3 stars from me.

This is a very nice place near Russel Square. Very attentive and friendly staff, yet not overly engaging.
The food was very nice, but even the "mild" choices are somewhat hot. My wife loved it, and it was okay for me (happy wife, happy life 😎).
You have several choices of rice, it is not included in the a la carte choices.

Very friendly and helpful staff. Not all vegetarian dishes were marked as such, but they recommended us some very nice ones. We loved the Portobello Mushroom appetizer, but also the traditional Indian dishes that tasted authentic to us. Prices were reasonable as well.
Really interesting restaurant slightly different to normal Indian cuisine but very tasty.

I expected better food. It turned to be average. I had the special byriani, it was greasy and had little meat. The menu looks interesting, maybe the other options are better.
They charge you 12.5% service charge but the service is poor.
Nice sushi bar. Flavour is richer than other chains in London. Good choice too

Used to be my go to place for sushi at lunch but with my last few visits the rice in the sushi has been horrible. A solid lump of stodge. I thought it was a one off but it's been the same the last three times. It's a shame add the fish is still nice, just ruined by the rice.
Great sushi but a tad pricey. great for a quick lunch with some seating upstairs. They have a discount 1 hour before closing.
Fantastic Noodles. It is one of the best noodles I have ever tasted in my life.
Friendly staff and decent food. Miso Soup very watery unfortunately...

I am not one to write many reviews but I feel this deserved one. My friend and I dined at this fabulous restaurant last Friday, and we both left feeling SO happy after having such a great time. Our waiter Cameron was so attentive and wonderful. He knew that we were celebrating my engagement, but also saw that we were celebrating my friend’s new job. After we had our food (which was so delicious!!), Cameron brought over two beautiful fruit platters saying “Happy Engagement” and “Congrats on the new job”. He went the extra mile to make both of our special moments memorable at Crazy Bear – we were left so touched by this thoughtful gesture. The manager coming to our table to also congratulate me on my engagement was also very thoughtful. The toilets downstairs, are a must-see! Both stunning and interesting – gave us all many giggles. Thank you Cameron, and everyone at Crazy Bear for such a wonderful evening. We will be back for sure.

Lovely sushi and well presented, very friendly staff and good service. Shame about the giraffe taxidermy hanging and floating above the stairs, not very flexible with dishes and don’t offer many vegan or vegetarian options. However, would definitely return as the food all in all was delicious  ☺️
Great service. A touch cramped around the table. Good food, not spectacular but good. A nice atmosphere and service make it worthwhile

This restaraunt definitely showed it's "crazy" side. The decor was very different and very intriguing. I had the duck in tamarind sauce with Jasmine rice which was mouth watering! I went with a friend on a Wednesday and on this weekday you get 50% off on champagne bottles! It's quite a pricey place but understandable due to its lovely food and atmosphere.

Everything was too sweet. Really sweet. Food was just ok (which is not great for the price you pay). Service wasn't attentive but when there very lovely. The surprise-toilet was a normal toilet basically. The atmosphere was nice, almost romantic and dark.

I have been eating here a good number of times in the last 2.5 years. While I was very impressed when I first discovered Pied à Terre, I think that this restaurant is not able to maintain its high standard.

Unfortunately the quality of the food is inconsistent if you chose the 10 course menu. Some of the dishes are absolutely great and creative, but then there are a few that really fall behind. Last time I was here in the beginning of January, the dessert was rather disappointing and the vegetarian 10 course menu that my wife had, was clearly not on par with the non-vegetarian version and it looked like the cook was running out of ideas.

Furthermore, I have noticed that Pied à Terre is selling discount vouchers on Groupon. As a client who has been here multiple times and always consumed for 400 £ or more + tip, I find it disappointing to see that this restaurant is giving a 30% discount to those who are smart enough to search google for it. I am not a fan of discounts, and I think a Michelin starred restaurant should not do this. Regular clients who come here with their families, business partners and friends don't appreciate this.

The tasting menu was good, the wine pairing and the sommelier great. Overall not bad but very very overpriced for the quality and service. Yes, it has had a Michelin star for 20+ years butnit hasn't really evolved since then. It's been sat on those Michelin laurels for the 80s and doesn't feel like it's progressed at all. Good for a one time experience but certainly the business doesn't have repeat customer focus in mind. Shame, but no better than average for London.

Since reopening more than 10 years ago after a devastating fire Pied-a-Terre then the proud holder of two Michelin stars has struggled to maintain its high cooking and staff standards. One thing that it has maintained however are prices which are no longer good value

All the dishes were incredible, high quality from preparation to presentation and absolutely delicious. 
The end of this amazing evening was to invite us to meet the head chef, the kitchen crew and the owner 
An absolutely memorable experience 
I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone

PaT offers everything you would expect from a Michelin starred restaurant: knowledgeable sommelier, politeness, excellent execution, great flavours and ambiance.

I highly recommend the deer and pork mains.

I wouldn't say I was particularly surprised by anything that was served ... it is also worth noting that one could go to Roux and dine at 2/3rds of the price.

However it was very enjoyable and I would go back again.

I stayed here for two years 2016-2018. The College is extremely supportive and I was lucky enough in my first year to meet the Queen. As a musician, we had a few practise rooms. The pianos won't be as well-maintained compared to the ones at the conservatoires, which is expected. Musicians were also all very encouraged to host concerts. I really enjoyed my time here and it's sad to leave :'(. 

Come! : )

I have lived there for a year as a postgraduate student.  When investigating it, I looked at google reviews, so I thought I'd give back.  There were  some hesitations I saw on a couple.  Honestly, they baffle me now.  The facilities are excellent, especially in William Goodenough House where I stay.  The community is warm and vibrant.  The events are constant, varying from "Port Talks" on various subjects, to student concerts, to trips throughout England and even three a year to continental Europe (for those selected, there is an application process).  I went to Venice on an opera trip.  But that's a small point compared to the year round facilities and atmosphere.  And location!  Amazing place to be be, in the center of London, on a quiet beautiful square.  Also, whoever was criticizing the wifi: never had a problem.  Work great.  Come!
It’s not the best college but it’s Good Enough...

A beautiful events venue besides a postgraduate residence open to students from any university or college. An absolutely quite library with mainly fiction with visitor entry less than an hour.. Very receptive people.

I am a current resident here. The facilities are very good and the staff generally efficient, although always behaving too formally to be called friendly. They take in a lot of US students and Canadian students, as well as people from the richer Commonwealth. So this is not the most culturally diverse experience, as there aren't that many British, Europeans, and poorer-Commonwealth and developing countries people staying here. There are a lot of activities, but many are formal (you really need a suit to go to many of the events here). Like the a commenter who disliked it on Yelp said the place is full of people 'who like to dress like their fathers'. They have a Chaplain rather than a secular psychologist to offer 'counselling'. The ethos is still very much stuck in a British Empire mentality. Also from my own personal experience living in an all male corridor there is also quite a bit of public macho behaviour going around (last pearl I heard was: A: 'I'm staying in London for Xmas'; B: 'For a girl?'; A: 'Nah man, I would NEVER do that for a girl'). Many of the neighbours here don't even say hi when they meet each other on the corridor or the street, and just blank whoever they don't think is cool enough or part of the in-crowd in my corridor. So this place offers frequent encounters with people who are self-centered/individualistic, passive-aggressive, and have an inflated sense of self-importance. If you don't care about that  / are unfazed by idiotic behaviour and just want a place with excellent facilities to live in close to uni then Goodenough does offer that.

CLOSED for improvement works until early 2020 (they originally said January and then spring 2019), check the web site for updates.  Great shame as there is now a bridge from Gassholder Park across the canal to its entrance. Wonderful small and tucked away haven of wildlife - transport yourself into deep woodland right in the heart of Kings Cross. Theoretically it is level access but it's sadly not suitable for wheelchair users because of a lot of woodchip and uneven ground.

Camley Street Natural Park is currently closed and there's nothing to see except wasteland. Were it not for the Coal Drop Yard outdoor shopping centre nearby, I'd been really angry. There's a notice that says the park will be closed until sometime in 2019.
Really nice architecture. Much workstations but nice to walk by.
Loved it, a little bit of the country in the city, you can just sit and take it in. Need to go back.

A place to chat with good friends over a cup of hot drink or two.
Update: the park is now closed until spring 2019 for refurbishment.

Beautiful place to visit. One of the best displayed Museums I've seen. Manageable size and friendly knowledgeable volunteers. You can avoid the Holocaust section.  Interesting even if not interested! Nice cafe too.

Such a brilliant museum. Gives a brief introduction to the faith. The main part of the museum gives a brilliant insight into the stories and history of Jewish people in Britain, from the Normon conquest to modern day. There is a brilliant balance between the general history and personal experiences. It taught me so much I never knew. Also visited the exhibition "Jews, Money, Myth". So, so interesting and insightful! Wonderfully curated. There was printed texts on the walls of a conversation between the director and curator, giving insight into the reasons for what was exhibited and what was not and the reasons why. I would definitely recommend.

Good insight into Jewish history. Very large section on London history some of which is good some of which is terrible (suffering, poverty) - reflected well. As to whether to immerse yourself? Wait till they have exhibition or a peculiar on So you get to see one more floor
A well appointed museum that is easy to see in 4 hours. The displays are well lit and the descriptions easily read. Well worth the visit
Nice and interesting museum full of Jewish and Israeli history and even more.  Small cafe for a quick lunch. Would recommend it as Camden Market very near by. Wish the ticket price was lower..

Near & clean station. Lots of shops to shops including foods, drinks, clothing, accessories, decoration etc. Easy connection with Kings Cross Station, Bus Stops, taxi etc. Wide footpath to walk. Ticket counters have enough staffs and self buy ticket machines are easy to use too. Trains and platforms are good too. Lifts and escalators are available to use. There is toilet facility as well.

Clean and quiet, I went fairly early in the morning, so there was a not a soul in sight, stores were closed and everything was fresh and ready for the morning crowd, it feels like an airport and there is a lot of stores and things to look at here for a departure or arrival, I was heading to France. The design and style is nice for talking pictures and leaves a good impact, being that is was nearly empty, I had an easy time taking pictures and exploring the area.

Really nice lower floor with lots of shops and free toilets. Good interchange between train/international train/tube. However, the top level where the national trains come in is absolutely freezing without said toilet facilities (or at least, if there are loos, they aren't obvious), however an iconic ceiling.

Extremely rude and ableist staff who couldn’t give a hoot about helping people rather than just standing around doing sweet FA.

A beautiful station for sure and it has the Eurostar which is the best and quickest route out of the U.K. so it’s very welcomed.

Lots of shops in the station and signs are clear.

Just plan your journey and make sure you don’t have to deal with the belligerent staff here

One of the better stations in London. It’s clean modern beautiful and bright I in particular love it at Christmas time when they put up festive decorations. Convenient shops located inside and outside around the station, you can tell it is an old historical building but they have made it to look really good

Highly recommend. Me and my boyfriend had a really great time. This place is very cozy and has a good atmosphere, the service was good, the food was wonderful, the beers were exquisite, was very fun and I really enjoyed my time here.
After a long and bad day I ended up leaving this restaurant with a big smile. If you're looking for a quick bite and nice time with someone special or just even just a nice evening with your friends, this is the place.
Nice restaurant with pretty delicious food. Good quick service, friendly staff. Food was fresh, hot and tasty. Good prices especially for deals. Great choice of drinks, beers, wines and cocktails.
Great bar for after work drinks. 241 cocktails Friday (£10). Good food. Good vibe. Recommend

The vegetable casserole (a veggie tagine with couscous and some flaked almonds) was delicious. Spicy but very lightly - just what you need. Nice portion. My friend had mussels and fries and said the cooking and flavours were perfect.

Belgium styled restaurant with minimal vegetarian options. A pick and mix of the menu can create a meal but nothing extraordinary. We'll presented and proportioned servings. 
Tables are pretty packed in so no sense of personal space. The back to back bench felt disruptive.
Service is hit and miss. At times staff are attentive and welcoming at others just dismissive and distracted.

It was a cold wet day on Chalk Farm road but don't let that dissuade you. Ice cream tastes good on warm days and cold days. 

Marine Ice has yummy ice cream and decent portion sizes. It hit the spot after lunch (at The Lock Tavern). If you're in the mood for ice cream it's by far the best choice for the Chalk Farm Rd/Camden Lock area! 

p.s. If the weather had been warmer we'd have eaten lunch outside, in The Camden Lock Market, from one of the ethnic places.

A great place in Chalk Farm to get a delicious ice cream and a really good cappuccino. Very pleasant staff. We sat outside and really enjoyed soaking up the local atmosphere in the warm sun! Good shops nearby and near Camden Market. Also reasonably priced. There is parking across the road, pay and display, not expensive.
Price went up; 1 scoop is £2.40 and it was good but I didn't think it was wow. Not sure it's worth to go all the way there for ok ice cream Plus I didn't find their staffs friendly nor welcoming.
Lovely ice-cream. Good venue
Go in winter, the best time to nosh on delicious ice cream. Pretty reasonably prices, and lafger than expected servings!

Near & clean station. Lots of shops to shops including foods, drinks, clothing, accessories, decoration etc. Easy connection with Kings Cross Station, Bus Stops, taxi etc. Wide footpath to walk. Ticket counters have enough staffs and self buy ticket machines are easy to use too. Trains and platforms are good too. Lifts and escalators are available to use. There is toilet facility as well.

Clean and quiet, I went fairly early in the morning, so there was a not a soul in sight, stores were closed and everything was fresh and ready for the morning crowd, it feels like an airport and there is a lot of stores and things to look at here for a departure or arrival, I was heading to France. The design and style is nice for talking pictures and leaves a good impact, being that is was nearly empty, I had an easy time taking pictures and exploring the area.

Really nice lower floor with lots of shops and free toilets. Good interchange between train/international train/tube. However, the top level where the national trains come in is absolutely freezing without said toilet facilities (or at least, if there are loos, they aren't obvious), however an iconic ceiling.

Extremely rude and ableist staff who couldn’t give a hoot about helping people rather than just standing around doing sweet FA.

A beautiful station for sure and it has the Eurostar which is the best and quickest route out of the U.K. so it’s very welcomed.

Lots of shops in the station and signs are clear.

Just plan your journey and make sure you don’t have to deal with the belligerent staff here

One of the better stations in London. It’s clean modern beautiful and bright I in particular love it at Christmas time when they put up festive decorations. Convenient shops located inside and outside around the station, you can tell it is an old historical building but they have made it to look really good

Amazing service, food and staff. The value is incredible and the 3 course deal is by far the best in the area. It’s hard to come by great customer service, in such a busy environment,  but this place has nailed it, not only with a smile but a fantastic atmosphere. The meal sizes are great. Will be back for sure. To the gent who served myself and my family, thank you very much, everyone was overwhelmed by the service.

Someone call the police: this is criminally good value for money. 

If you’re a fan of a quirky interior look no further than this restaurant. It’s candle lit and quirky with buckets of atmosphere. 

The food is tasty, uncomplicated and the service is charming and faultless. 

I had the vegan option, stuffed peppers topped with vegan mozzarella. My father had the beef goulash and we both wiped our plates clean. 

The wine washed everything down very well and was a lovely Italian red, we had cheesecake for desert and polished that off swiftly too. 

I only wish we didn’t live on the other side of London, but next time we’re in the area we will be back for sure.

used to be an avid fan of this place when they were in Farringdon, but whilst their staff was great and friendly, and their atmosphere is still just as good, their food was definitely not up to their old standard. The duck and lamb mains were both lacking flavour (perhaps salt?), and the lamb was quite under cooked. On the plus side, the pigs cheeks were delicious, so not everything was under par.

Still represents a great value place to eat - if they get their food quality back up.
Have been coming here for years, cannot get enough of it. Reasonably priced great service delightful hidden gem in Kilburn. The decor and atmosphere is just wonderful.

We’ve been lucky enough to visit here a few times now and bring family on occasion too! One of my favourite restaurants in London. The atmosphere is always great, as is the service and the food. Would always advise pre-booking especially if you want one of the high seated booths over looking the restaurant. Lovely wee restaurant!

I had some old notes that needed changing. I was told that I may have to queue up to an hour at the exchange till to get them changed. However when I got there there was hardly a queue at all and I was in & out in about 10 minutes. The member of staff who served me was really friendly & helpful.

The parts of the building that the public were allowed in looked spectacular. It was very reminiscent of the scenes in Mary Poppins with the 2 elderly bankers.

Visiting the Bank of England museum is a lesson in Economics and a good venue for school trips. It is free to visit, very well organised and you can also take a free audio/visual guide which contains a large amount of information on each room. Apart from learning about the role and function of the Bank of England, you can learn about the production and development of Bank notes, from the early days of hand written transferable  promissory notes for gold depodits to the modern note. It was fascinating to see the old notes of the 1960's which I just remember; The large printed one pound note.

What a great moment for all  intellectuals.. to be appointed as governor of Bank of England,  gentleman Meritorious and intellectuals are always recognised and honoured.
The post is currently (present governor) worth 874000 pounds a year, the highest paid banker in the world.

We visited here from Canada, back in mid-August.  (We believe they are lucky to have Mark Carney :) ) The mini-museum was amazing, just to look at the whole history of money and banking.  Our two young daughters were enthralled by it too, being able to do some hands-on activity like controlling inflation and assembling bank note puzzles.  The history of literary figures in money was a good exhibit.  Lifting the gold bar added a nice touch too.  All in all, it's worth it!

You can change your old Pounds for the new ones. 
ONLY BILLS, NOT THE COINS.

Fast and friendly service. It took only 5 minutes.
The tour guides are amazing, rally nice people and full of knowledge. The place has a really interesting history.

I attended this church for 3 months when I stayed at Premier Inn. I’ve seen choirs from States visiting on many Sundays. The Pastor noticed me visiting and chat with me many times asking me where I’m from. When I told him I’m from Singapore, he told me he actually stayed in Singapore in 1960/70s . An unbelievably nice Pastor but there not many assistant Pastors and he seemed to be working alone. In my Singapore Faith Methodist Church we had 5 pastors and numerous staff to help out. A very memorable visit to a church where John Wesley started his work. His body is buried in a nearby cemetery!
To kNow history and his travel across world and how he did that by road in 1707 is good to know .
Another one of London's lovely secrets. Very moving and inspiring.
Beautiful church in the city, love the windows.
Amazing historical place. Quiet
Wonderful Royal Mencap Carol Service with Music Man Project and English Baroque Choir

Surprising historical find in the centre of the much more modern Barbican development. 

Very pleasant brass band can be found rehearsing on Wednesday evenings.

Grade I Listed and much rebuilt medieval church rich in associations with numerous notables over the ages,  nestles aside The Barbican lake terrace, London Wall remnant and London Girls School. 
Historic artefacts and accoutrements in a restored and subdued interior. 
Regretfully the bare immediate surrounds with the exception of a few trees is denuded of colour and supportive context. 
Bring on the landscapers.

Mainly know it as my local polling station and once for a classical concert from the local school.
Nice building and surrounded by old headstones etc dug up when the Barbican estate was being built.
Interesting stained glass window on West end showing the modern City of London skyline a few years back with No 42 or the old Nat West Tower as it was known before, being most recognisable

Beautiful victorian building which is like some sumptuous art gallery within with statues and marble. The gallery is an interesting thing to do to see justice metered out. You need to get there early and leave your phone and cameras at home as they are not permitted. Also a very interesting experience to do jury service here! Not far from St Paul's tube station and the Museum of London
If you want to watch a case get there before 10:00. You get to hear some great cases

"Oranges and lemons" say the Bells of St. Clement's
"You owe me five farthings" say the Bells of St. Martin's
"When will you pay me?" say the Bells of Old Bailey
"When I grow rich" say the Bells of Shoreditch
"When will that be?" say the Bells of Stepney
"I do not know" say the Great Bells of Bow
Here comes a Candle to light you to Bed
Here comes a Chopper to Chop off your Head
Chip chop chip chop - the Last Man's Dead

Head in the morning and try to find space in a gallery in an interesting trial. It's nail buying stuff often and you'll want to return the following day to hear what else has to be said! Highly recommended if only to see our justice system in action. Need to spend at least 30mins in the gallery
Top one Judicial

Amazing what you see when walking this city rather than taking the tube. This church, also known at All Hallows Barking has great history. The oldest church In London founded in 675AD is full of history with a lovely example of a Roman pavement in the crypt. Hidden gem.

Not only is this a lovely and very well maintained church, which was repaired after the Second World War, but its crypt houses a small museum. This museum has artefacts and documents ranging from the marriage register entry for John Adams but also the birth register entry for William Penn. It also has a Saxon Arch meaning that church has been on this site for many years.

A delightful and historic church, a stone's throw from the Tower of London.
A previous vicar was Tubby Clayton, founder of TocH, which offered hostel facilities to soldiers in the Great War.
The church hosts many activities for outside organisations, including two church music guilds of which I am a member. Also weekly lunchtime organ recitals, I believe on Fridays.
There is also a restaurant facility attached called the Byward Bar. Well worth a visit.

We visited the oldest church in the city of London today and were in awe by it's longevity. The exterior and exterior appeared to be worn yet in solid condition considering it has been around since 675AD. That means it's well over 1300 years old! Simply remarkable. A very nice lady gave us a tour in the crypt, located below the church. It was very interesting to learn about its history. If and when you're in London, please check this out.

The church is absolutely beautiful and a quiet heaven in the heart of the City. 
There is a small museum underneath the building and also a cafe.

Spring is a wonderful time of year here, with a terrific range of forest floor bulbs and plants. There are many scented shrubs and lots of seating for unexpectedly warm days at this time of year. Look out for the carpets of violets from mid March complemented by the late flowering pure white daffodils. A joyous place!
I love this place. Very peaceful. I often go here to photograph the wildlife and people.

Beautiful historic cemetary containing the graves of several famous authors including William Blake, Daniel Defoe, and John Bunyan. It is also home to some squirrels who are very friendly unless the resident fox scares them off.

A fine resting place for several eminent people, it also acts as a small bird sanctuary. Not all of the graves are generally accessible, many are behind locked gates and railings. I imagine that you can access by appointment. Graves include William Blake, John Bunyan, Daniel Defoe and poor Mary Page; see photo of gravestone.

Burial ground of many non-Conformists including John Owen, Isaac Watts and John Bunyan. Most of the graves are visible, but be aware that some require permitted access by staff as they are in the fenced off areas. A peaceful, secluded location hidden in the bustle of that end of town.

If you're in Thailand and looking for Sunday worship. This is a great English speaking Anglican Church. Services are Sunday morning 7am and 10:00 am English worship. 1:00 pm. Thai whorship service. They have Sunday school for the kids. Potluck lunches after the service to meet and greet.
Nice playgroup on Wednesdays and Fridays. The pastor is very kind and we enjoyed the Sunday service on Easter.
Really moving experience-great interaction with sooo many cultures.
The Christmas morning service was lively and awesome.  There are washrooms (even for the disabled).
A true reflection of God's people a place of worship with dignity I love this church for all people come and be blessed
Offers free and often very interesting lunchtime lectures. Located within Postman's Park which is well worth a visit.

A really beautiful church next to Postman's Park.
Really friendly people and engaging.
This is a beautiful church in the City of London.
Really nice!!
Historical church associated with Wesley family.Other than service time the entry is through the park side and heritage exhibits open to visitors. Intersted in Christianity can enjoy it.
Beautiful interior. Very friendly reception from 'attendants' who were happy to show round and point out the interesting features.

Visiting London doesn't have to cost a fortune. Here is a perfect example of something interesting and completely free! Free entry. Free spacious and clean toilets. Free guided tour to tell you all about the history of the City of London through paintings mainly but there is also the remains of a roman amphitheatre in the basement.
Highly recommended.

Worth visiting if you are in the area. Entrance is free, and you get to explore the gallery as well as the ruins of the Colosseum in the basement level. The gallery is well organized with explanations on the wall. 

The place is one of the less busy attractions and the staff are very friendly.

Awesome art gallery! The cherry on top was the roman amphitheatre beneath; it looks like something out of the hunger games. Amazing art collection with artworks from all over the world and with many focusing on London. There's also a parchment with Shakespeare's signature on it which was interesting to see. Would highly recommend going!

One of the hidden gems of the City of London. 
It is a fabulous art gallery showcasing some great Victorian masterpieces.  There are some amazing paintings about london as well.
One of the most interesting this about the gallery is that it contains the Roman amphitheatre (an ancient monument) in its basement. A must see

Quite a surprise really as I never expected the art works here to be so good. It's free entry, I was also very luck as I arrived just as a "Free Tour" was beginning. Our guide (Amber) was very bubbly, fun and enthusiastic. She brought a selection of the paintings alive by explaining the background to the painting and her interpretation of the scene portrayed. The gallery is represented over 4 levels, with the basement level given over to the archaeological revelation of the roman ruins of an Amphitheatre.
The free tours of the gallery are on these days and times: Tuesday, Friday, Saturday: 12.15, 13.15, 14.15 and 15.15.
There is a lift providing Wheelchair access to all floors.

It is a very good place to visit where you get to learn something new. This easter holiday my nephew loved his trip to the museum. The authority arranged an activity through the trip, which he has been most attracted to. At the end he earned some precious rewards too. However, for adults there are lots of information to know too. Enjoy.

Decent place to have a look around. Entry is free. Some basic exhibits about currencies and explanations of how elementary macroeconomics work, which seem to be aimed more at children. You can also pick up a gold bar, it is worth going for this alone.

One of the Museums that is not extremely interesting for kids under 5 years old. But for adults this place brings new experience of touching real gold as well as tons of facts about money  and financial system. Definitely worth attending and spending a couple of hours there

Really great experience, interesting to get to know about the British economy and to look at all the different currencies over the years and the many other exhibits. It wasn't too crowded and there were plenty of interactive things to do making it suitable for children also. All around educational and interesting and plenty to look at

This is a free attraction. The museum takes about an hour to walk around  (more if you stop to read everything). The history mostly looks at banking in the United Kingdom and a history of the Bank of England itself (as the name suggests). There are interactive exhibits but I didn't feel these gave great examples but they are likely to keep younger people entertained. You can actually touch a gold bar. I was more interested than I expected to be.

Some hilarious baysic B8 reviews on here.

It’s a phenomenal place, it is inclusive, beautiful, has our door and indoor spots, water works, theatre, music, cinema, art, shops and places to eat.

Even coming here on a sunny day and just to relax is lovely.

The conservatory is only open Sundays but totally worth a visit.

Some staff may have an airiness issue as they think they work in the best place in the world but that’s rare, everyone I’ve spoken to here has been friendly and polite.

The overall structure is beautiful and interesting but look further at the little details as they are amazing.

Took away points as I am a member of corporate membership with the Barbican and incompetent staff failed to honour all the terms and whilst ignorance is understandable for the staff member to lie is certainly is not, or to ignore the Barbican issued corporate membership card and the details written on it.
Good place to hang out by the lakes especially when sunny and both the hall and theatre put on some good shows. 
Some of the exhibits outside that can be quite good, although some may have quite a queue like "Rain" or can be a trifle expensive.
Conservatory, which is free is open Sundays and some bank holidays and certainly worth a visit. Nice to see the water birds there including a heron which is a regular visitor, maybe from Regents Park

Possibly my most favourite place in London. Love the atmosphere when going for a gig or just hanging around to do some remote work. When you book a concert make sure you get in early, get a quick buffet dinner in the canteen an then just sit in the lobby and wait for the show or go and browse the arts shop.

Quickest way from Barbican station to Barbican Centre:
Take the stairs to your left just before exiting the station, this will bring you to a bridge over the road. After the bridge, continue along your right until you reach the stairs of the Defoe Building (see picture). Take the left stairs, then turn right and continue walking along the Defoe building for 200 meters. Take the stairs down and you're at the Lakeside Entrance.

I loved this place, many different spaces for different purposes. Only sometimes when busy some areas are left dirty.  Did you know sometimes there are stage plays available  at affordable prices. The staff were efficient.

Lovely, friendly museum. Very small and slightly confusing curation - they've tried to cram in a lot of stuff, appealing to adults and children alike! Follows the progress of the St John's Ambulance from its formation in 1099 to (almost) the present day - there's a lot to cover in just three rooms. That said, it's free and has a small shop - well worth a look if you're in the area.

As one of England's most notable knights of St John reenactors this place is a must for learning about the history of the order. Steeped in history and like a tardis if you want to step away from the hustle and bustle of London step inside the tranquility of the orders sanctuary. Lots of displays and regular events for children.
Too much to see in one visit. The Order was once the biggest private landowner in Britain.  Don't miss the Caravaggio (he was a knight before expulsion)
Very enjoyable, interesting place. If possible, visit the lecture room upstairs. Amazing!

Amazing staff know what they are doing,  great extra info for my son's school projects. Really was a great day out.
For almost nothing.

The National Firefighters Memorial is a memorial composed of three bronze firefighters in action during the Blitz, in Second World War. So you might be mistaken in thinking that the memorial is only to firefighters of the war. In fact, the memorial is for all firefighters throughout the United Kingdom who were killed in the line of duty.

The statue is a little uninspiring, but I admire the sentiments.

I love this memorial. It really captures the true heroism in the spirit of these firefighters. The way they risked their lives to save others. The memorial really makes you feel like you are there at the Blitz fire which took place in 1940. The 'Second Great Fire of London' is another name used at the time to refer to one of the most destructive air raids of the Blitz, over the night of 29 to 30 December 1940.
This place will make you think about those who sacrificed their life for others.
The National Firefighters Memorial was built to honor the men and women who bravely fought against fire on the streets of London during the Blitz of World War II.
Nice place to visit on your day out.

Very interesting to visit. Through the tour, you understand the history of Lloyd, how it transform from a coffee shop to insurance market place which still running and growing fast. Problem is this tour is not open to the public. You need to be nominated by someone who is working inside in order to join the tour with very strict security check. Formal dressing is a must also.

A private tour through Llyod's of London brings the rich history of how, why, where and what into perspective. A global titan in reinsurance and the marine industry, we come to appreciate the tour and how it came to Singapore and helped us become specialised in the marine sector.
Not well signposted and once there it is a very frantic environment. I had to ask three times before the front of house team could properly direct me to the correct room.
Paid out nice and quick when my ship was lost round the horn
Fascinating building. All staff were very proud of their building and happy to talk about it. Great views from the meeting rooms.

London Stone entered national history briefly in the summer of 1450, when John or Jack Cade, leader of the Kentish rebellion against the corrupt government of Henry VI, entered London and, striking London Stone with his sword, claimed to be ‘lord of this city’. It is much older than this, however. It's said that if the stone ever leaves London, the city will fall. Easily one of London's oldest landmarks it's regularly ignored by passers by who don't even know it's there.

Went to see the London stone expecting to see a historic landmark and something special. Literally it's a block of stone and the date and original purpose of the Stone are unknown. All we really have is some speculation about it's original purpose and use over the centuries.

A bit pointless when there's so much to see in London.

The most beautiful stone in all of London. I had goose bumps just being near it. If only I knew what the stone represents perhaps I would be in love with it. Nevertheless it still remains an ancient stone like most stones. A stone is a stone until you find one that gives you that special feeling as this stone will. So now I have been stoned by the stone in London and have something to talk about at high tea. Fairdinkum Mates, no worries, cheerio.
