Food and service are good. Good selection of Italian wine and food. Fresh and well done.

The food was good and so the service, but the wine (30£) was brought to the table already opened. I’ve never expected something like it, not even in the worst gastropub. I wonder if that is part of Michelin star’s policy.

My hubby and I went there back in October on a middle Saturday afternoon to find some really good quality live jazz. It was such a great atmosphere, busy with good service at the bar. Love the way the bands are made by amateurs players who are put together and changing at every 3 or 5 songs.
All done quickly, not letting the audience waiting much, perhaps just giving us a chance to get another drink without missing anything. We enjoyed this place so much that we booked a hotel in Soho as we could have another night in London to visit the bar.

. Cozy pub next to Carnaby street, with amazing atmosphere. Live music performances of proper blues, many beer and other drinks choices, friendly staff and people around!

Would definitely recommend it to my friends and all, who wants quality music. They have musicians performances every night with a surprise note as there might be a gig of random people playing at once as well! 😍 ❤️

Ain't nothing but good vibes! Xx

Genuinely the best blues bar in Central London. Do lovely Ale and always has amazing music. It's a great crowd and it gets very crowded- but good door staff there always stop it getting too crowded. If you want to lose yourself in some live blues then this is definitely a place you want to see!
Good music. Good beer (not cheap). Good people and staff. Worth taking a look. Crowded and not much room. But cosy as hell.

This place was by far my favorite place in all of London!  It has the best music and a perfect multicultural vibe.  Went alone and met a ton of awesome locals who made me feel very welcome in a city so different from my home in the U.S.   Such an amazing experience! Be sure to get there early though, not much seating but by the end of the night no one is sitting so not a biggie if your legs can handle a long stand.

A place with a historic background, visited by many people every year. The manor house recently underwent a professional restoration. This place served as a tea house for those in reign many years ago. 

"The Manor of Bexley was acquired by Henry VIII, and remained a part of the royal estates until James I sold it to John Spielman in an attempt to raise funds for the crown." Wiki.

Subsequently, the location of Danson mansion is inside a 17 acre plot of land, known as Danson Park. 
It has great footpaths all around, parking, sports/ boating facilities and food/ drink facilities. 

My favourite place is the secluded garden, which is routinely maintained. It can be found opposite the mansion and adjacent to "The Stables" (public house). 
The park as a whole is great for a nice walk. It is common to see wildlife residing there. Near to the secluded garden is a sports and leisure centre. It's about 10 minutes walk.

X Children's playground
X Summer Water playground
X On site toilet facilities
X Public house
X Tennis courts 
X Bowls
X Boating lake
Beautiful location, lovely afternoon tea although the cafe is rather small inside

I’d attended my citizenship ceremony last Saturday and it turned out to be a very pleasant experience. The staff is cordial and the venue is very well restored with sprawling greens. Though not sure about the cafe, had a cursory look through their menu and found it to be a little overpriced. However there’s a pub (Danson Stable) in the same vicinity which offers great food and drinks for a price totally worth.

Wind whipped and forlorn with commanding presence over an endless lawn. The 200 year old Bexley Charter Oak ( one of London's 20 most important trees ) a lonely sentinel overlooking the lake. 
Authoritative but not endearing here. Fortunately the park surrounds offer an appealing alternative destination.

Excellent place to spend a day out with family/kids.   Big boating lake where you can feed birds.  Big and very well maintained playground for kids of all ages.  Kiosk, where you can buy coffee, snacks or some warmed food,  tables to sit and toilets (reasonable standard) available close to the playground. 
Danson Stable pub is popular and serves good food.  However we did not like the burger from the kids menu (may be because we went there within the very busy hours), but kids fish and chips are amazing.
The caves themselves were a worthwhile tour. The guide was knowledgeable. However ticket office staff were very slow. Food took about 15 minutes but was plentiful and tasty.

Those caves are certainly very interesting to see if you are looking for something to do away from Central London but still commutable. 

These caves are man made and served as a shelter for people to survive during the wars. The tours are only with a guide, as there are so many tunnels and junctions that one would easily get lost in no time. And due to the nature of it being caves, some spots are in absolute darkness. 

The tour guide was super friendly, experienced and had lots of interesting stories to tell about those caves. 

We have been shown the dorms and the church down there, which was super interesting to see, as people made the best out their situation. It is hard to imagine to live in total darkness for quite some time, and the only light source being your torch. 

The guides provide with oil lamps which you carry throughout your whole visit. Our visit duration was about 2-3 hours. But you might have to add 1 hour waiting time to it, as they only let a certain amount of groups into those caves. 

Parking was adequate for us, but there is the Chislehurst train station literally next door, so arriving there by public transport is no problem at all. 

The trains are coming from London Bridge Station, and it take about 30-45 minutes to get there.

We went to the caves on a grey day, but it certainly cheered us up. The stories of war times and beyond were good to hear, if you take young children be sure they are not afraid of the dark and very enclosed spaces.
At one point the guide takes all the lanterns away and I have never been in so much blackness,. You really can't see your own hand in front of your face. Interesting.
They also have a very reasonable cafe, but the gift shop can be a bit pricey. Well worth a look!
Amazing place to visit! Cheap to get in, staff are friendly and helpful and the caves themselves are full of hidden gems, steeped in history. Can't wait to go again

Went with my husband, daughter and grandchildren, aged 6 and 10.
The person who did the tour was great, he made it interesting and fun.  Chislehurst caves have a small gift shop and a lovely cafe. The food was very good value, and they make their own cakes etc!
Good parking right outside. Would definitely recommend a visit!
Excellent day out!  Fascinating. Beautiful surroundings and the story of a remarkable man. Don't forget to join English Heritage for free admission and to support our heritage 😊
Had a lively visit . The audio tour was very informative.  The house was very well preserved and you can feel at home in the rooms. The gardens were pretty too
The 'Mecca' for people believing in evolution and a must go place for those who don't. Lovely presentation of his life and times there. Very informative.

Lovely place! Exhibition is nice, you can learn a lot. We kind of had a private tour with one elderly gentlemen, one of the volunteers, who toured us around the house and told us incredible details of Darwin’s life. The garden is worth seeing too. We went in autumn and there wasn’t much to do but I guess it would be worth going another time of the year.

Slightly disappointing. The upstairs museum display seems rather 60s, with random objects in boring display cases. Garden limited and doesn't really seem to reflect the Darwin era. Shop does a good impression of an off-licence. No photography inside, but nothing much that is photogenic. If he had 7 children, shouldn't the table have 9 places? I seemed to have missed a display of his books, drafts, first editions etc.

A lovely experience at one of London’s most famous landmarks. It is currently under going maintenance though. It is a classic London sight, easily accessible by multiple means of public transport, or by foot when walking around. It’s a great, classic monument. Very glad they are looking after it so well and to it being around for a long time to come. I Love this place so much, its a MUST go location.

Great, famous Big Ben. When will you be cleared for visitors?  With the scaffolding of work around the view becomes more interesting at night, when the monument is illuminated and the work appears less.  Either way, it makes up the look of the city, a view that is very beautiful from the top of the London Eye.

The House of Parliament and Elizabeth Tower, commonly called Big Ben, are among London's most iconic landmarks and must-see London attractions. Technically, Big Ben is the name given to the massive bell inside the clock tower, which weighs more than 13 tons (13,760 kg).  The clock tower looks spectacular at night when the four clock faces are illuminated.

Big Ben is among one of those landmark that comes immediately in mind when you think of London. But unfortunately when I went there it completely covered and can't see anything as it renovation work is going on. This is located at superb location at Bank of river Thames and have easy access by the Tube and bus route as well. This is One of must visit places if you are going London for first time. :)

The Big Ben is glorious, one of the most famous landmarks globally. Its truly a beauty when the sun is setting. The architectural detail is phenomenal. London is a must visit primarily for this single attraction.
History

Stumbled across this on one of the few days it's open to visitors. Would highly recommend going if you're looking for something a bit different. The volunteer tour guides (especially Lois) are extremely dedicated and knowledgeable while the rest of the volunteers are cheerful and helpful. Fascinating stuff with more history behind it than you would think!
Excellent exhibition

I had no idea this was here. My father, who was visiting from America, wasn't in the mood to go far and was looking for something off the beaten track (but still on an easy bus route) to check out.

The solution: The Shirley Windmill

It's open on day a month (or something to that effect), but we didn't go on whatever day that happened to be. Instead, we walked up, walked around, took some pictures, marveled in this rural relic of Victoriana, and then went to lunch a bit further up the road.
Is a beautiful windmill, perfectly conserved, great to visit, unfortunately is close during winter.
Love this windmill
David Lean Cinema, wonderful place to see a film. Bar outside, take your drinks in, couldn't be better.

Lovely bright and light venue with nice decor, well layed out with good convivial lively atmosphere however let down by food. Chicken breast grilled with tomatoes garlic and butter meal woth cake included. Chicken was overcooked and very dry and chewy. Side salad was wilted and limp and chips were probably at their best an hour before ordered. The cake wasnt the delicious looking gateau displayed on the counter but a wafer thin squashed slice brought up from under the counter. Coffee was good. Overall disappointing, great venue let down by the cooking of what should have been a good menu.
Beautiful building.
Meeting T Braithwaite hall
I liked going to my Performing Arts courses with my tutor Jim and his assistant Navind in CALAT Central Croydon Centre on Thursday afternoons from 12:30-2:30pm.

Under refurbishment at the moment, have had the pleasure of helping with this myself. Set to be beautiful when it re-opens later this year (2019) with ample parking or a short walk from the station located just up the road.
Nice inside and well laid out but it's location is awkward. There's a small car park if your lucky or more likely a fair walk if your not.

At present Faifield Halls is being refurbished and is due to reopen in September 2019, although I used to come to this theatre back in the 70's and 80's and was a fantastic venue for concerts and shows, hopefully when works are complete this venue will be even better!
Still under construction hoping to see soon

The Fairfield Halls puts on some great shows and I can only complement them for this. I have enjoyed every show I've seen here. However, the building is well overdue for being renovated, something I believe is planned very soon.

Update:  2017 - March 2018 Works are well under way after a delay of about a year. The contractor only seems to employ 7 people at one time as you never really see many builders on site so god only knows if the building is going to be open on time. Only part of the building has been pulled down & nothing (externally at least) much seems to be moving.
Staff are very helpful and the gardens well kept
Not clear clean all full thing must be good grass full out old weeds leaves everything stone damaged throw away check name person year keep good have garden plant everyone special arrangement service

They were so good with me when my son died  at the age of ten days old they made thing so much more then saying good bye to him they made me feel I had had friends support me thanks to Them they made it easer
Nicely maintained.
Perfect experience from the beginning to the end .
An interesting plaque. Seems that the stone will be moving soon.
Booting not worth wasting your time
Great place for a Goodgym meet up!
The stone on which the first English kings were coronated. Now housed outside the Kingston upon Thames town council buildings.

Great piece of ancient Royal British history, and many locals don't even know it's there. 

Believed to be the Coronation Stone of seven early British Kings prior to the Norman Conquest. The Kings Stone explains the name of the town it’s in.

SO NICE TO SEE IT'S ALL RESTORED NOW FOR THE 30'TH ANNIVERSARY!
Such a beautiful sculpture to see but it has been left to rot and it's in urgent need of restoration. Kingston council is spending a lot of money on constant roadworks all around the town centre. Just opposite this sculpture, the road was laid just a few weeks ago and it has since been taken apart again! Who answers and takes responsibility for this waste of time and money? Perhaps Kingston council should spend some funds on maintaining the history of Kingston, not just on roadworks.

It's local and it's a sculpture, although put together with redundant call boxes which are a true London icon. They have recently undergone a clean and renovation to mark it's 30th anniversary. There are various prints of the sculpture available online.
I remember when it was being installed,still looks good now
There also like a plaza, lots of shops there, not only to take a picture. You can walk around
I walk / drive past it almost daily. It is now deteriorating a bit, could di with a little TLC, a coat of paint the odd panel / pane of glass replaced

Has multiple courts (20+) and of course the central court is as beautiful as a pearl. 

The central court can seat more than 15,000 spectators. ((Wish I could watch a match there one day.)) The public ballot, for the tickets, is open from September to December every year.

The club has 370 full members and around 150 honorary members. Becoming a member is very cheap ((just £99 per year)) and fairly easy ((you just need a reference from 3 existing full members, wait for one of the existing members to relinquish their membership due to death or otherwise, the wait generally lasts about 20 years)). 

All the courts are very well maintained with all the sophisticated instruments.

You should visit even if you are not a tennis buff. So very well maintained. Good guides to take you around. The entry fee includes the guided tour. You will watch every Wimbledon open after seeing this place.

I loved the experience.  Such an intriguing history when it comes to the world of tennis
 The entire tour was great and our guide, what an awesome person he was. Definitely has all the history at his fingertips. The paraphernalia shop was also great.....selling branded history in different forms....you will definitely get a gift of your choice if you are a tennis lover.....was quite difficult for me to choose a gift because everything there was attractive.....ended up getting a fridge magnet, a mug and keyrings......Do not forget to do a museum tour as well.
Definitely worth a visit. Ticket includes museum and an excellent guided tour. See my Wimbledon review for more details and pics

Absolutely fantastic experience! Very well organised tour which was highly informative and interactive. To see and be part of something historic is amazing. The cafe inside is quite good and I loved their chicken and mushroom pie :) definitely worth a visit any time

Always a pleasure to bring the family over and again we were well looked after over the weekend. The Mother's Day menu was exquisite and the service was great. We've been coming for years and the standards of service and the quality of food have been consistently excellent. Having Indians to compliment the food says it all!

There is a lot to say about this place but it would spoil the tasteful experience. All anyone needs to know is that Cinnamon Culture has beautifully presented, deliciously tasting Indian food, with a twist. Perfectly modern. The service is really great too. Definitely worth more then one visit.
Great meal last night. Fresh food full of flavours, generous portions with attentive, friendly service at reasonable prices. Ticked all the boxes and I'm happy to return soon.
Had forgotten how great this place is and the midweek prices are great value.

Food was delicious (I'm very particular when it comes to food!) and waitress was really nice.  Came here for my thank you/ leaving meal and was glad I chose this place.  Will definitely return for a personal visit.
Taste is good and spices are so great
I didn't visit
It's a very good place to enjoy with friends and family
Best place
Great place

Popped in for an impromptu birthday lunch for my son and daughter after visiting the London Dungeon. Although it was a busy Saturday afternoon, we were found a table quickly and in a great position next to the conveyor belt. The staff were fantastic, always ready to help and the food was great. It was fresh and of  excellent quality. Dishes ordered from the kitchen arrived promptly.
The best thing however, was the staff helping with secretly adding my candles to the desert selection plate. When they brought it out, it looked better than I could have imagined and the two staff members sang happy birthday to my 11 year old son.
Will definitely visit again.

Fantastic dining right by the Riverside, friendly staff very attentive and efficient, recommended to us the chocolate pots which were heaven in a cup! Really tasty, I'm a fan of the new fries too! First time I've visited since the menu change and I can definitely recommend it! Go outside your comfort zone and try some of the new dishes, it'll be worth the experience for sure! X

We had a great time at yo sushi! The food is awesome and the service is even better. Literally both waitors were really nice but Nicole really stood out. It was our first time here and she helped us choose the best dishes and was kind and helpful all the time 
 We enjoyed this restaurant and would definitely recommend it and come back!
Had a great time at Yo Sushi. Loved their vegan menu. Lots of choice and they even have a vegan chocolate dessert. Delicious. Thanks to Harry for the great service too.

Spend your money somewhere else. Sushi is less than average and you can easily spend 25 pounds in just 2 or 3 really small portions ( 3 units). I would rather go to a good place and taste something that worths the money. Here is all about the fancy place near London eye. I totally regret it.
Great food and kind personnel!! Would totally recommend for people looking for Greek cuisine at reasonable prices. The only thing missing was the music background.
Ordered their lamb casserole and it’s perfectly cooked. Good vibes inside with quieter outside seatings available.
Traditional Greek restaurant both in quality but also portions and price. Highly recommended
Easily the best agreement restaurant in London and my favourite go to place. Food is amazing and the staff are incredible.

I love this little Greek restaurant in Notting hill. It feels so authentic as if I was in Greece. Such a beautiful buzz (always busy). It’s a family owned restaurant and both the owner and his son are always around working. The owner is such a lovely man, he comes and chats to the costumers and makes them feel welcome. And the food yummy! Try the prawns and allll the dips.

Fantastic experience we all had! The food was cooked to perfection and we had no complaints. The staff were fantastic and very accommodating. The atmosphere of the whole restaurant was lively yet intimate. The live music was a treat. Prices are mid-range and excellent value. Portion sizes are great. Will definitely be visiting again.

An absolute hidden gem in Croydon! Food is excellent value for money and the decor isn't like anything you've seen before. When booking, request a booth! Only downside is that it gets very hot in there and doesn't seem to have any air con? Great for couples, friends or family meals - kid friendly too. Looking forward to our next visit!
Lovely food, service was great. Very different setting but was lovely to get to sit up in one of the theatre booths. Would definitely go back again
Amazing as ever.. my all time favourite restaurant.. fantastic place.. food delicious and good quick service.. also live entertainment... just love it xx

I usually love this restaurant. This time I had a very specific reason for requesting an upstairs booth for an occasion for someone with certain needs. I requested several months in advance and followed up a few days before and was assured my request would be honoured. When we got there we were allocated a downstairs table  in a busy area and told it was not possible to honour my request. It caused not just ‘disappointment’ but was hugely stressful for that person, who had a bad experience. Will not bother going there again, but rather somewhere you actually get what was promised.

OK-ish customer service the food was good but the big mushrooms in the Old Orleans burger it was watery in which I did not like maybe I just don't like mushrooms in a burger,
But over all it was good, don't think I go crazy on it but it was a change from the norm..
It is not here anymore, it is now Harvester.

The staff was the rudest I’ve ever seen in a long time. One of the girls with a tray full of shots was walking around the dance floor and hit my friend from behind whilst she was dancing and forced her to pay for all the shots as she blamed her for dropping them. On top of that, after telling her it was 44, she actually typed in 55. So my friend paid 55 pounds because the rude, clearly not very careful staff member was walking around the DANCE FLOOR where my friend was DANCING and hit her from behind when clearly she couldn’t ever even have seen her coming. The manager had a super rude attitude when we complained about it and tried to sort it out quickly giving us a couple of free drinks. Awful experience. Bad music. Rude staff. London is full of clubs, don’t waste your time and go somewhere else. Oh, and on top of that we paid a very expensive cover, on a Monday night..

Nice party place with lots of people to talk with. There are happy hours like drink+drink. Unfortunately, no big place for dancing and not many chairs to sit. You can go there with the group. The security won't let you go there all alone.
Coolest club I’ve ever been to, very clean with three different huge DJ rooms. Felt extremely safe due to how much security was there and how intense getting in was.

Good party vibe... However.. Do not drink the Guinness here. I ordered a Guinness which was placed in front of me 3 seconds later, it looked like coffee in a pint glass with no head ,,staff seem ill informed to what it's meant to look like. Charging £5.80 for slops is pushing the boat

Love this place!!! They have lockers for your things to store which you pay with a credit card. They key you wrap around your wrist. Do not take a lot of stuff you will be in the water most of the time. I recommend some cheap slides/sandals to walk around because the concrete could get hot and for walking on the beach side. I love the Rapids. The slides are awesome but try not to "sink" your butt into the floatation device because you can get injured (they have signs). Take a waterproof camera not your cellphone. Take sunscreen. You can leave your towel. They have towel stations. You will be taking many photos. Jewelry, earrings, watches, rings should be left at home you do not want to lose them. Go early and enjoy. They have upscale shops, casino and restaurants to eat. Beautiful resort!! I will be back!

WOW!  We stayed at The Cove, which has a spectacular pool for 18 and over, and were completely blown away with this resort.  We were there during spring break and the place was packed.  Even so, not once did I feel like it was too busy and service from every staff member was superior.  Friendly, clean and over the top fun every single day!  Great casino with craps tables, even by The Cove pool.  The aquarium was out of this world!  I could go on and on!  Highly recommend for anyone.  We will be back!

Great experience. The entrance is similar to City Walk and Disney Springs, there were a number of shops and places to get snacks or meals and was well manicured. 

The aquarium was terrific and had a wide variety of sea life and different ways to interact, including touching starfish and large windows at different heights and angles that allowed for great photos and videos. There was a lot to like and enough to see that it separated groups and allowed everyone to have uninterrupted time at different exhibits to take photos without being crowded.

The beaches were clean and while heavily populated were not hard to find seats and seats with umbrellas. Just off the beach, you had access to typical tourist food (hot dogs, nachos, fries, etc.) and on the beach they offered locally designed and made items, local fare, including drinks in coconuts which were a hit. As alcohol was optional, nearly every person sitting on the beach had one.

Great time, start to finish. Great for kids, adults, etc.

Stayed at the Royal Towers. Nice air conditioned rooms. Spacious rooms and cleaned daily. Despite being in the Caribbean the rooms smelled very fresh and clean. Overall the service was outstanding. Please note, we were told that the mini fridge was weight sensitive. If we either took something out or added something, it would automatically bill us $50. Needless to say we didn’t open the mini fridge. You can also check your bill via the TV on the main page. A nice feature. We had the casual dining plan so our meals were already pre-paid. I did have to dispute with the front desk about some charges on my account regarding our meals. The front desk cleared those charges immediately after being notified that we already prepaid through our dining plan. Overall, I would go back in a heartbeat. Very nice place to go. Wonderful beach.

On the last day of our trip, I put my 7 years old in line for a slide. When I was not looking, a staff member cornered him and ripped his wrist band off his arm. She didn't even ask him for his parents but instead humiliated him in front of other guest and made him know that he was not welcome. When I saw my son he hung his head down and explained to me what happened. He was confused and absolutely distraught. 

When I went to the Atlantis staff for an explanation and to let the them know that under no circumstances should anyone have touched my child without my consent. They told me to wait for a manager. I gave them my name and room number and waited an hour for the manager to come speak to me and provide and explanation and apology. During the hour wait, I and my youngest child had to sit and wait and could not enjoy the park.

When the manager finally arrived she explained that they were suspicious of my family and that out wristbands were invalid so they called the hotel to confirm that we belonged on the property. There was no concern for the trauma and public humiliation they put my 7 year old child through. I showed the manager my room key and the pass that I purchased for Atlantis and after confirming that our access to the park was valid,  there was still no apology. They derailed our entire day, mistreated my child, and the manager refused to remedy the situation. I will NEVER visit Atlantis again. There are many great things about the property and many helpful staff members but I have NO praise NO tolerance for anyone who mistreats my child.  My family was made to feel unwelcome. My son still has not processed the treatment he received.

I must say where the first manager failed other mangers including the life guard manger, towel manager and Power Tower manager were very helpful and sympathetic. They did what they could to ensure that my son was okay and could get on slides but as I stated earlier it is very difficult to move on from such a negative experience with the cruel treatment of my child.  Inconsistent customer service and poor treatment was a recurring theme for us at the Atlantis as earlier in the week, I asked the young lady at the Atlantis front desk for directions to the lazy river. She told me I needed a day pass and started quoting prices. I showed her my 5-day pass she asked me when it expired as she laughed in my face. It was clear that she was not going to answer my questions so I walked to the check in counter where they helped me.
What a wonderful restaurant. Great pasta dishes and amazing staff. Worth a trip!
This was a very pleasant discovery. Food was very tasty and the service was so nice! Real Italians :)

Been going to this place fro special occasions ever since i was a little kid - even know some of the staff as friends now and it will always hold a special place in my heart. So friendly and warm and the food is delicious and fancy but also incredibly wholesome, like grandmas special secret recepie. My personal favourite is the wild boar ragu, its an absolute win, and everything about it warms you from the heart.

Food are so good and the service is amazing 
Nice restaurant to search with friends and family
Great food, good price and friendly staff and good service.

Easily one of the best tourist experiences ever had. The staff/actors were brilliant and engaging. So much time and content for what you pay that it's well worth the money. Was worried at the beginning we had gone into something meant more for kids but it was just pure fun for all ages. Such a great experience.

I've been visiting the London dungeon for many years, even before it moved to City Hall and have enjoyed every visit immensely. The experience runs for over an hour and had some excellent funny and scary moments, while the actors are of a very high standard. New things have been added since our last visit which were equally brilliant. I highly recommend this if you're looking for something fun and scary on the Southbank. Buying your tickets early saves money and I was able to Dave even more money through my work loyalty scheme. Can't wait to go again!

Did this as part of a tour around London. Was not as scary as I would have liked, but it did have some surprise factor. The interior was dark with visibility when needed to see the scary stuff. It was busy with tourists when I visited which made the vibes good. I recommend you give it a try, at least one time.

We went there with our class from Germany, and it was awesome. The actors were great, the ambient was incredible and the fact that the actors sometimes even involve the audience makes it one of the best experiences I had in London. I had no trouble understanding the actors, but a few other people did. You shouldn't bring young kids under the age of 10, and even then you should really consider if that's a good idea. I would absolutely do it again, 10/10!

This was amazing! If you like your history its definitely the place to come for a fun day out. All the actors were great and the effects are amazing... there was lots of information and it all was so much fun though i wouldn't take young kids as its very interactive and could scar them. Overall a great experience i would even go again.

Always an amazing experience! This was my second time on the London eye but the first time for my kids too experience it! We had a blast! There is so much to see and the ride is a really long ride so you feel like you get a good amount of time in your container pod.  So many great spots and things to get pictures of while you are on the ride. Highly recommend!

One of the most iconic places in London. Easy to get to from Waterloo Station. Its always busy. Great Tourist Place to take pictures from of the Thames and London City. You can book tickets on the day or online. What an amazing experience. The view from the top was astonishing.
Its worth it!

The main thing - the ride - was obviously pretty nice. I liked the view and the atmosphere. 
Now to the reasons of why I only gave it 3 stars:
1. The waiting time. I've waited approx. 1.5 hours - even though I had the most expensive ticket!
2. The room in the cabin. Maybe because of so many tourists waiting, I don't really know: The cabin was a little bit too full. Now I know, that not everyone needs a sitting place, but I believe many tourists use the tour as a pause from their city trip.
3. The view. Don't get me wrong, I liked it. But for the London eye to be described as one of the main attractions of London to go to - it wasn't good enough. Now the problem here was a pretty funny one (not really): One of the parts of the London eye obstructed the view, which then results in approx. 20 sec of obstacle-free view above London.

For a glorified Ferris wheel this was pretty good. My group of friends was able to get the student rate, so that was good. We also all went together I a single pod, so that was also good. There were 12 of us, so small groups may have to be with us people. We also went at a later point in the night on a Friday, so there was no line. The staff was very friendly and nice! Would definitely recommend the view from the top, even on a cloudy day.

In an era where text messages are the norm, love letters are believed by many to be a thing of the past. While shooting your loved one a text saying that you miss them can be a great thing, why not show them how you really feel by sending them a letter? Do you have someone in your life that you adore? Show how much you appreciate him or her by giving them a unique and thoughtfully-written love paragraphs.

Many of us might not be used to writing letters anymore. But there is something incredibly romantic about a letter, especially when it is written to a boyfriend, girlfriend, husband, or wife.

Loved this spot.  Protected from the elements for the most part.
Wish I had my board with me to carve a few lines.
Hope this guy managed to nail the landing!
Historical place. Great to skate, you just gotta know you'll like a Zebra in the Zoo because people will watch and photograph you 😁👌🏼

Free skate park in the city is great! Although it’s not a very big park, I love that it’s so open to the public that families, kids, tourists can all stop and watch the skaters doing one or two tricks.
A place of incredible culture! Awesome place to skate or just watch skaters. This is true London heritage- long live Southbank
Best place to go in London plus Go Southbank team get the undercross open

Well restored national theater of Athens. Two venues inside the same building, the old historic one, beautifully kept, and a smaller space for more experimental theater. Always top level theater performances of the National Theater. You just can't go wrong by attending a theater performances there. Always too quality level word, and totally not staid!!!

My favorite theater in Athens. The building is amazing and the time you spend there always with hight quality. The area is not that safe but it worth it. Take the metro and choose omonia metro station. It is like 2’ walking from there. Do not hesitate to take an outside photo and of course to enjoy any event, just to realize the unique feeling. Sometimes there are offers on the tickets.
Such a superb place to be. Great theatrical plays on the stage, historical building with modern commodities - stage, lights, new wing!
A great theater for great plays, always enjoyed when I visit
Theater always decent but sometimes excellent

Been here a few times now. Lovely place for a special occasion. Not cheap but reasonably good value for money. Had a lovely table this time, right by the window which offers fabulous views of London. Great food, good service. We plan to return.

Absolutely delicious food catering to a wide range of diets, from vegan to meat-eaters. Ambiance is between cozy (lighting & seating) and smart, with, definitely recommend a smart-casual dress code at the least. 
Service is amazing, the staff is extremely pleasant and reactive. Do recommend you indulge in both entrée and main course - knowing that there's quite the selection of dessert, which, if you're already full, people will quite happily share.
It's an iconic part of London. Just walk through it or stop for a coffee, or meal. Great views, make sure to go to the boutiques or to the back and find the quieter oasis in the city
A great place to visit. Dinnned in the top restaurant. Was amazing. Staff so friendly and attentive. Loved the place. Would definitely recommend.
I like it but it is missing something to become even better. Need more creative input than just reply in the location.

Definitely a place were you can spend a few hours. Surprisingly enough, there is an enormous amount of things to explore and learn about, let alone take wonderful pictures of the neighbouring sites of London. If you are interested in how the crew of a warship from WW1 lived aboard one of the most famous ships on earth, visit the HMS Belfast!!

I knew as i walked there that it was very impressive to see how ships in times of war looked like you could feel als you walked there if you were in that time period as I self love history of England this sure does fascinate me! You could really go here if you have young boys or teenage boys as they can be informed about a bit of the past. This is still quite astonishing to see as its also very cool and is a real good thing to visit as its  good  to  see  a  bit  of  good  old  History.

My father served on her guarding the artic convoys in the war, so it was a trip down memory lane for me. She's a beautiful ship, who earned her place in the history books.  Explored all nine decks, fascinating insight into what life would have been like at that time. Definitely worth a visit.

Friendly staff, great visit to the HMS Belfast.  So much to see and nearly all areas of the 6 or so floors are accessible.  Kids need to have long enough legs to climb the ladders - reckon 6 onwards myself.  My youngest is 7 and managed well enough.  Opportunity to sit in the captains chair and see some good views too.  Well worth a visit.

Went to the HMS Belfast for the limited time Escape Room. Found the staff very friendly and informative and very passionate about their job. The HMS Belfast has been kept in fantastic quality, even though those wax models are super life-like and kind of creepy. Nevertheless, The HMS Belfast was a beauty. I do recommend leaving several hours to explore slowly to get the most for your buck. Have a good one!

Not a lot to see, but what you do, is a piece 
of real history. Easily missed. No entry fee.
Just by the road.  Beautiful rose window.
To pass by when going from Shakespeare's globe to borough market. My walk started in st Paul's cathedral, millennium bridge and then this street with beautiful treasures.
Great to view while enjoying a coffee right next to the structure

We had a 6 hour layover at the airport so we spent a few hours in Winchester.  This was a beautiful area and I highly recommend the trip if you have a layover at Heathrow.  The castle was incredible as expected

It’s a wall of Winchester Palace, there is a plank with some information on the side. Not much to see. But it has a lovely rose window that you can see. There’s a little garden inside as well. It’s a lovely bit of old London in the middle of new London. Free to see, so if you’re passing you might as well see it. It looks amazing at night when it’s all lit up!
A beautiful cathedral, so much history to enjoy. We popped in during evensong and listened to the wonderful choir. Really good gift shop. If you want to take photos you need to donate £1.

It is ethereal. I went to this cathedral for a American choir concert by the Durham school of the arts, North Carolina. It was brilliant to watch, and to listen to the beauty of real music. The cathedral itself has a café and also spaces for art exhibitions. I would definitely go back. It is very close to the London Bridge station and also the London Bridge.

Lovely and often overlooked cathedral on the south bank of the River Thames in London. Deceptively big inside with lots of nooks and crannies to explore. The cathedral has a good refectory serving nice food. They also have good conferencing facilities available for corporate events. And being just across the road from London Bridge station, it is really easy to get to. Well worth a visit.
I went to choral evensong. First time I'd been to a church service for many years. It was beautiful. Even as a non  believer I could appreciate the history and tradition.

Well worth a visit, there's more to this place than it looks. We had a guided tour. I strongly recommend you do if you can as there is lots of remarkable history. Our tour started at 11:30 and was so interesting that  it was 1pm before I knew it!  The 'Refectory' is a good cafe with wide selection. Don't miss the garden and Mohican memorial

What a great find! The place has a unique vibe that makes it stand out from other bars on the South bank. I was amazed to find out that it actually used to be the studio of Polish artist Feliks Topolski!! You can enjoy a delicious cocktail, whilst being surrounded by history and artwork, and I can't think of a better way to spend my Friday night.  Friendly and helpful staff made sure our experience was at its best - Thank you! Definitely coming back!
Good little place to have a beer on the way home from London to Waterloo. They have happy hour between 5-7 where you can get 2-for-1 bottles of Moretti! Highly recommend,
Nice bar.. very close to the London Eye.. the pizza served are different and very very thin. Happy hours Buy 1 Get 1 until 7 PM on weekdays.

Great bar, good choice of drinks 
And music. I sound old when I say this but music volume is great as you can easily have a conversation with people. Haha.

If you like your bars dark and edgy, with a more industrial feel, this is the place for you. The beers are limited but the cocktails are better than you might expect, especially their old fashioned. The simple  flatbread pizzas deserve a shout out - delicious and great value.

I had to give this 5 stars because of how scared and the adrenaline rush I had on the last part of the experience when going through the Tombs! I was only in London for the weekend, but this was one of the best experiences me and my partner had. All the staff and actors throughout the experience were brilliant, 100% effort from all, including the members of staff out on the street with the que who were very helpful. Overall it was a very enjoyable experience and would definitely recommend it to anyone visiting London.

I would say this was one of our more memorable places on our trip.  It is educational and a little scary.  It starts with the educational stations and then they line you up to go through the scary tombs.  Not too bad at all and the ice cream at the end is awesome.

Was really fun experience, a good scare and interesting facts and history about the London Bridge. Highly recommend trying this out. On a plus note, you finish at Creams dessert and you get 20% off. Lovely!

Visited in May 2018 with my niece and nephew but the experience is still one that comes back to me. 

It’s something I should have reported at the time but chose not to because it didn’t make any sense. When entering the event, you are told that the actors will not touch you at any point, and you are asked not to touch them. 

About 3/4 of the way through during the final ‘tombs’ part of the tour, a few times you have to squeeze through what look like two large black mattresses sandwiched together. Upon emerging from the last of these, I distinctly felt someone or something put their fingers along the back of my neck in a very quick scratching motion. It was definitely someone’s fingers, and not a cobweb or something, I could distinctly feel the force behind it and the individual digits of the persons hand. 

It was not the visitor behind me because we had to put our hands on each other’s shoulders and hers were clamped tight and did not move until the gift shop at the end! My initial thought was that an actor chose to bend the rules for some reason, but I didn’t see any in the area. I don’t see any other accounts of being touched here in the reviews, so I thought I would add my experience to see if anyone else has had a similar time to mine. It was seriously spooky and something I can’t seem to forget about! 

Also, the guy chasing you with a chainsaw out of the exhibition was scary, you could smell the fuel, it was real but it just had no chain on it! 

We got our moneys worth and I can safely say!

Great and scary attraction situated near London Bridge and very conveniently across the road from the London Bridge underground station.  Not for the fainthearted or under 18's.  Enjoyed this attraction and would recommend for a visit.

Been here a few times now. Lovely place for a special occasion. Not cheap but reasonably good value for money. Had a lovely table this time, right by the window which offers fabulous views of London. Great food, good service. We plan to return.

Absolutely delicious food catering to a wide range of diets, from vegan to meat-eaters. Ambiance is between cozy (lighting & seating) and smart, with, definitely recommend a smart-casual dress code at the least. 
Service is amazing, the staff is extremely pleasant and reactive. Do recommend you indulge in both entrée and main course - knowing that there's quite the selection of dessert, which, if you're already full, people will quite happily share.
It's an iconic part of London. Just walk through it or stop for a coffee, or meal. Great views, make sure to go to the boutiques or to the back and find the quieter oasis in the city
A great place to visit. Dinnned in the top restaurant. Was amazing. Staff so friendly and attentive. Loved the place. Would definitely recommend.
I like it but it is missing something to become even better. Need more creative input than just reply in the location.

Although the Thai food was quite nice. The server was not.  I noticed he treated me and my daughter significantly different from other diners there.  Had to go to the counter to get a spoon for our tea and saucers. He was ignoring us throughout . I will not be going there again.
Always amazing. Favourite Thai place in London. Proper Thai vibes, cheap as chips, quick and really lovely folks. Often a queue coming out the door, but always worth the wait.

Marie's does great thai dishes at good prices. The lunch deal is especially good value, and very filling! The only downside to the place is it's size - if you go in a group larger than 4 then it's difficult to sit together, and you have to squeeze between tables to go to the toilet. Otherwise, it's a good place for a quick, cheap and tasty meal.
Great little cafe for work lunches. Really reasonably priced. Quick service and output if you are on a tight schedule. Jacket potatoes are really nice and the breakfasts are good too!

Completely unpretentious venue (think something canteen style), solid food. During the day they serve English breakfast dishes, at night it’s Thai food. I recommend it for both. It’s byob. I think this is a good spot for a quick meal on the go without any fuss. Expect it to be very busy at night. The service is fast and hasty.

Only there Friday, Saturday and Sundays. Fantastic choice and never had an issue with  quality.  Shrimp burgers are definitely my favourite but had Malaysian curry, duck fat cooked chips. Recommend giving it a try. Disabled parking right next door.  Don't Park on the path which happens to be the same level as the road you'll get a ticket.

Some new food choices at this center. Not as crowded as borough market. Still have a variety of choices. Can sit and eat on the stairs, another plus. Now there is variety of cuisine including some good Mexican fare for stateside folks.
Very good..... so much choice! Plus you can have a great craft beer. You will find yourself sitting wherever you can get! Love it....

Food galore from popular corners of the world. It is a must if you are a food lover and like experiencing the new. If not, there is always the familiar. Even you have just eaten, the fusion of aromas and smell of cooked food wafting in the air, will be enough to make you hungry again. Be prepared to pay premium prices. Enjoy.

Food heaven.  It's as simple as that.  One of the best things about London is stumbling upon things like this.  It's just behind the Royal Festival Hall in a bustling setting. The food quality and variety is spot on.  No matter what your dietary need or preference, you'll find something to love here!

I'll almost always make a beeline straight here when I get off the train at Waterloo.
Excellent wine collections. Food is great and love the feeling under the bridge. Ask the staff for suggestions of wine.

I went to Vinopolis for my hen do and really enjoyed the experience. It was great to try wined that I normally wouldn't have. The measures were a good size, so you could really taste the wine, but didn't get too drunk in the process. The staff were very knowledgeable. I would have liked to try the deli board but I do think this is over priced. The lecture on how to wine taste, was very good.

Amazing selection, wines and spirits. They offer tastings, and there's a tour to walk with some informative and interesting pieces. Worth poking your head in the door if you're nearby and like discovering new wines.

The ambiance is outstanding in Cantina Vinopolis.  It is a bit on the expensive side, but if you are looking to impress out of town guests or a hot date, this a great place to go.  As you walk through the doors into the Cantina, you have the bar to your right, but as you keep going straight you will go into this massive room with brick walls all around and beautiful wooden tables. In the back is an open kitchen, where chefs dressed in all white work away.  The restaurant sits underneath the train lines, and it has a wonderful warehouse feel with super high ceilings of exposed brick.  The food was good, but nothing out of this world.  I had a the pre-fixed menu. It was nice. I visited this place for a business dinner, and our guests from abroad were very impressed with the general decor of the restaurant and the neighborhood in general.  This sits near Borough Market underneath all the train arches, and surrounded by cobblestone streets.  The restaurant does not have any windows to look out of so it is best to come here on a cold or rainy day.

Vinopolis is a great place for those who want to discover more about wine without having to travel to the caves of France or Italy. The tasting sessions are quite pricey but highly worth it as you get to try quite a few wines from their selection which is broken down by geographies and flavours. I discovered a great chocolate wine as well as one that had a very distinctive caramel flavour. Vinopolis also has a cocktail bar on the side which has a great selection of house cocktails and a great 2 for 1 offers in the evening.

Always an amazing experience! This was my second time on the London eye but the first time for my kids too experience it! We had a blast! There is so much to see and the ride is a really long ride so you feel like you get a good amount of time in your container pod.  So many great spots and things to get pictures of while you are on the ride. Highly recommend!

One of the most iconic places in London. Easy to get to from Waterloo Station. Its always busy. Great Tourist Place to take pictures from of the Thames and London City. You can book tickets on the day or online. What an amazing experience. The view from the top was astonishing.
Its worth it!

The main thing - the ride - was obviously pretty nice. I liked the view and the atmosphere. 
Now to the reasons of why I only gave it 3 stars:
1. The waiting time. I've waited approx. 1.5 hours - even though I had the most expensive ticket!
2. The room in the cabin. Maybe because of so many tourists waiting, I don't really know: The cabin was a little bit too full. Now I know, that not everyone needs a sitting place, but I believe many tourists use the tour as a pause from their city trip.
3. The view. Don't get me wrong, I liked it. But for the London eye to be described as one of the main attractions of London to go to - it wasn't good enough. Now the problem here was a pretty funny one (not really): One of the parts of the London eye obstructed the view, which then results in approx. 20 sec of obstacle-free view above London.

For a glorified Ferris wheel this was pretty good. My group of friends was able to get the student rate, so that was good. We also all went together I a single pod, so that was also good. There were 12 of us, so small groups may have to be with us people. We also went at a later point in the night on a Friday, so there was no line. The staff was very friendly and nice! Would definitely recommend the view from the top, even on a cloudy day.

In an era where text messages are the norm, love letters are believed by many to be a thing of the past. While shooting your loved one a text saying that you miss them can be a great thing, why not show them how you really feel by sending them a letter? Do you have someone in your life that you adore? Show how much you appreciate him or her by giving them a unique and thoughtfully-written love paragraphs.

Many of us might not be used to writing letters anymore. But there is something incredibly romantic about a letter, especially when it is written to a boyfriend, girlfriend, husband, or wife.

Best place to visit . It is found inside Addis Ababa university , College of natural and computational science compound .
Several wild animals are found reserved ( killed and dried ) 
It has entrance fee 
For regular students (AAU students ) and children - 5 birr
For adult Ethiopians - 15 birr
For foreigners - 100 birr 
If you want to record and take a picture you have to pay another fee .
But all the payments are totally worth it .
I RECOMMEND YOU TO VISIT THIS PLACE .
Museum was closed despite that it's supposed to be opened.  No explanations.  Don't bother going.
It is consist of historical and inspire objects.
Easy to miss. Still worth a walk through for the insect and mammal collections, modest though they are. Gives a sense of the biological  diversity of the country.

Worth seeing place, excellent to visit with kids, interesting and reach exhibitions, many kinds of different species of animals displayed, but also prehistoric part with interesting fossils and reconstructions of dinos, geological part with different minerals and gems and ethnographic exhibition. My son was just amazed and not bored at all - there were several kids corners to draw but what was the most exciting to him - there were exhibits that he could touch or play with!
You just dont know how large the exibition is when you arrive at the front door. Very well elaborated, easy to move inside the building. I loved.
It was nice and interesting but no explanations in English
A wonderful museum, especially for kids. You get to see and touch all kinds of animals. A must see of you are at Bergamo!
So many dinosaurs! Fun place in old town Bergamo.

Incredible building. We has an amazing experience whilst in London this weekend. The museum is free to enter but I'd highly recommend making a donation. The museum is full of so much weird and wonderful stuff. The building itself is a work of art and that alone is worth going for. The cafe was very nice, food great quality but slightly pricey. But you cant complain as it's free to enter.

This is my favourite museum in the whole world. There is so much to do and learn here, it's very amazing. The treasures room is a must see, along with the dinosaurs. The building itself is incredible with so much detail in the architecture and stone. It's better to visit on a week day because on the weekends all the families come with there millions of children.

Absolutely fascinating! The Victorian grand entrance hall is truly a cathedral to the natural world. Plenty to see for all ages - everything from minerals to the dinosaurs, with the blue whale being impressively huge! Expect the popular halls to be very busy, but other areas are more quiet. The cafe was very busy, but there is an area downstairs to take your  own food/picnic. Queues to get in on a Saturday - but the queues were moving quite quickly, so the wait was not too long.

An absolutely massive building with a ton of fantastic exhibitions. In many ways though the building itself is as impressive as anything inside it.
There displays on dinosaurs, which the kids love, human body, gemstones and a lot more. I spent hours in here and still didn't see everything.
1 slight downside is some of videos and sections are fairly dated and you can see they were done in the 1980's so some upgrading would be good. It still a must visit.

We spent our last day in London at the Natural History Museum. I couldn't believe this museum was free. It was beautiful, both inside and out, and full of amazing things to explore! The architecture is outstanding. The human evolution exhibit was really fascinating to me, but I think we all loved the blue whale skeleton and the dinosaurs the most. My 9 year old daughter especially loved seeing dinosaur femurs longer than she is tall! The "live" T-Rex did not disappoint either!

Really chill place. Beautiful. Lots of history and wonderful plants. The self-guided audio tour is really cool and easy to use. Very well  cared for and organized gardens. I was there in early spring and there was lots of life, so I'm sure it's absolutely stunning by midsummer.

It is always a pleasure to visit the Physic Garden even in the dead of Winter when nothing is at its best. Every plant has a history and the free guided tours and/or free talks check when these are before you go, are full of facts about them which will astound you. Snowdrops, Irises and Narcissus are the Kings and Queens  in the new year months of January/ February and the sheer variety and cost of the rare ones will surprise you too. The homely country style restaurant serves great food but be aware that if you are booking to eat you are still obliged to pay the £7.50 entrance fee. No concessions.

The best way to describe it was in the words of our tour guide, Chelsea Physic Garden is in itself a living library of plants.

Don't forget your student ID! The student tickets were about 7 £. A free walking tour is offered every half hour. The garden itself is well kept and so beautiful. If you prefer wandering on your own at your pace, there are also informative plaques to guide you. I think I would have loved to read a book here if I could spend my whole day at the garden. Do be careful as some plants are poisonous (there are signs that will warn you).

The entrance is on a side street and there is a cafe inside for you to eat at.

Fascinating insight into the botanical and medicinal gardens in Chelsea. Arrived just in time for a free 20 minute tour and had it not been for the chilly weather I could have happily listened to our guide for hours. 

An amazing array of snowdrops and flowers including the England's oldest olive and grapefruit tree. The gardens were also responsible for sending Cotton to Georgia, US. Worth a visit and for £7 it's decent value for money too.

An oasis of green tranquility in Central London.
Well worth the visit.
Membership is good value if you are a repeat visitor:

Beautiful rose garden, well maintained. Do come on weekends. Its located in sector 15. Space for car parking also available. You can enjoy coconut water, various flavor of ice creams, lemon soda. Best time to visit is in evening as it glows various colour full lights there. Lot of fountains with ample sitting space. Best for jogging yoga exercise, whatever you love to do.

The Rose Garden as the name suggest has different varieties of roses white , red, Yellow, orange,pink with a specific scientific name written...
The sizes of roses are also very Big.
The park is large and spread over 30 acres..
The garden is well maintained with good grass..
The trees also beautiful..
It also has a fountain..

Good to spend time here
Moreover eating facilities and washrooms are also available..
A Nala passes in between the park and has bridge to cross over it..

My mom used to come here when she lived in Chandigarh for a while. When I visited, it was nice. However, i noticed that the water (lake) was drained. It did not look very aesthetic. Wish they were fixing it at a different time. The flowers look very beautiful. If you are in Chandigarh, I recommend visiting this garden. It is also a great place for studying or reading (or relaxing in general). I just want to put out a request for people to not damage the flowers and plants. If you are taking photos, please be aware of your surroundings. This is a beautiful place, and we should keep it this way.

Visited during summer vacations and hardly found any rose. Summer definitely not the right time to visit the garden. There is not much greenery also to sit during summer. Recommended for other seasons. Kids did not enjoy much and all we could see was little squirrel 🐿 at entrance. Must be much better place during season other than summer.

Opened in 1967, this place has been one of the scenic beauty types place where you can visit anytime for nice views. The garden is well managed by the managing body. Also if you are one who is very fond of roses and would like to take a look at different varieties of roses, then this is the place for you. Also during the time of valentine's week, there is a rose festival organised here. So visit this place during this time and you will definitely worth it. For the rest of the year, this place is chic and quiet. So a good place for finding peaceful environment for a short time in a day or so
... nice spot for people and dog watching, boats for hire, benches to sit in, toilet facilities reasonably clean, nice place if you are into swans and ducks.
In the summer a beautiful place to relax and go boating. Well worth the walk through the park to chill by the river and see the ducks go by.
Perfect London Park! Wonderful for picnics in summer & cycling in winter. One can still escape in the long grasses & not be seen. Love a swim in the serpentine.

Beautiful water in the heart of the City.
Terrific boating. Whether walking around 
the lake or just relaxing by the edge, this 
is one fantastic place. Popular restaurant 
commands one end. While a beautiful
Italian Garden, the other. Easy access.

Beautiful place, clean, safe and fresh air in the middle of the city, lots to see and do here
For kids it's a must do place.

Kensington Gardens can be easily labelled as one the best parks in London. During a sunny day you can have the perfect time outside of the London crowded streets. There is a lots of hidden spots for a nice picnic. But you have to look for them. There is a lovely bar just within Kensington Palace and usually an Ice Cream van on the main road. This is also a very good place for jogging or for a family time. I would recommend to bring some bread and nuts to feed the birds and squirrels.

Green Parrots. Trees. Open space. Unlimited possibilities. Beautiful in summer and winter. Well kept and relatively clean and safe. Plenty wildlife to enjoy and quite busy most times of the year. Relaxing and peaceful.
Highly secure in a busy area as staff work on an electric gate, very handy as my son is autistic. Free to enter and huge area with a variety of things for children to play and learn on

A peaceful park around the Kensington Palace. I liked the walk in this park from the Natural Science Museum to the Buckingham Palace, through the Hyde and the Green parks. This one has big lawns, a lake, a Palace (!) and lot of animals - squirrels, waterfowl, etc. Nice to stroll around in the sun, in the first month of spring.
Princess Diana memorial play area is a great play area! Best for under 12's, and definitely worth the trip today to give the little one some fresh air.

Lovely well maintained park. I love the fact that you have to buzz in. Adults are not permitted on their own (if adults wish to view the park they can do so between 9:30 and 10:00 before it is accessible to children).
The park is great, it was very quiet when we visited as the rain had just stopped.

A really cool place for children to play they just love being in the sand and on the ship.  There's also a great adventure playground adjacent to the shipping section.  The only downfall is there are not enough places for parents to sit since children have to be accompanied by an adult to enter.  It's enclosed and safe with staff at the gate.

Absolutely amazing, a playground thought really worth the children in mind! Full of different apparatus for kids to climb and explore, this has been a wonderful discovery. Only one note, if you go there as one parent and more than 2 kids, especially if very young, you might find it a bit overwhelming.

A great place really. Excellent for letting the kids run wild. It's enclosed and guarded by an attendant who really checks what's going on. Great play facilities with a really nice pirate ship, wooden climbing castle and ramparts, wet play in summer, music and plenty of hiding places but no way to get lost. Good cafe, allthough as expensive as you should expect for that part of town. Bring a packed lunch!

My favourite playground to take children to and their favourite too!!! What a great place to keep children entertained and happy in the same time! It's perfect any time of the year! It's the most complete playground in London and children can spend hours and hours of fun without getting bored. Thank you Diana! 😍

Kensington Gardens can be easily labelled as one the best parks in London. During a sunny day you can have the perfect time outside of the London crowded streets. There is a lots of hidden spots for a nice picnic. But you have to look for them. There is a lovely bar just within Kensington Palace and usually an Ice Cream van on the main road. This is also a very good place for jogging or for a family time. I would recommend to bring some bread and nuts to feed the birds and squirrels.

Green Parrots. Trees. Open space. Unlimited possibilities. Beautiful in summer and winter. Well kept and relatively clean and safe. Plenty wildlife to enjoy and quite busy most times of the year. Relaxing and peaceful.
Highly secure in a busy area as staff work on an electric gate, very handy as my son is autistic. Free to enter and huge area with a variety of things for children to play and learn on

A peaceful park around the Kensington Palace. I liked the walk in this park from the Natural Science Museum to the Buckingham Palace, through the Hyde and the Green parks. This one has big lawns, a lake, a Palace (!) and lot of animals - squirrels, waterfowl, etc. Nice to stroll around in the sun, in the first month of spring.
Princess Diana memorial play area is a great play area! Best for under 12's, and definitely worth the trip today to give the little one some fresh air.
Beautiful, of course it is, as is all of the Royal Borough. I used to live in Church Street and walk every day in Kensington Gardens. If it's good enough for Peter Pan, it's good enough for me.
It’s really rather more of a soft rectangle with jut-outs on all four sides than it is ‘round’, but the joyful abundance of ducks makes the titular oversight forgivable.
Not very round unfortunately, but my friend loves the ducks here so it's good for them i guess
Beautiful. The ducks and swans are very friendly and greedy for food. Nice place to bring your children and to be in contact with the nature.
Ducks, so many and big ones. A serene place tk spend your evening nearby.
Great gym. The facility has many trainers with a great knowledge. Besides the spa is epic. Loved it. Been a great experience.

As a potential future member, I visited the club the other day and I can confidently say that I am not that impressed. First of all, on arrival the reception was attended by just one member of staff whom was caught up with 2 other members and so I had to wait around 7-10 minutes to be acknowledged. That gave me time to notice that the minimalist design of the reception was quite basic and needed refurbishment. It took them more than 10 more minutes and 2 calls from reception until someone eventually arrived to talk me through the membership options. He was a lovely chap, David and I was ready to be overwhelmed but in reality they really cannot justify the £210/month when there is no swimming pool and they only have a couple of studios for classes. I am guessing it can get quite busy in there. But they do have olympic level PT's there and fancy trainers that look like models. In reality, the main open space gym floor is quite stunning within this gorgeous Grade 1 listed building and the machines are top tech but at the same time everyone seems to be so perfectly toned and pretty, you may have confidence issues going there to train. The staff do smile nicely and make you feel welcome once you're through the doors which was actually nice and comforting. No doubt, overpriced Lulu Lemon plus other designer gym clothing was at sale in their shop, they do have steam and sauna rooms, own brand bottled water, a personal laundry service and £140 massages, just so you know. I failed to ask which of the extra services are included in the membership fee, but my guess is as good at yours. Perhaps none? Lost 1 star on waiting times and 1 more on the lack of swimming pool and high fees.
Terrible rude staff. Gym equipment is dated and it seems like the the place cleaned once a day, completely stinks and sweaty benches.

Equinox Kensington has an awesome variety of facilities and great service.
You can find a relaxed atmosphere with plenty of room and space to work out. 
The gym is absolutely clean and very well equipped. 
I would definitely recommended to anyone.

I love Equinox! As a member of the Equinox Sports Club in NYC, I decided the day I landed in London to do an Athletic Conditioning class in the Kensington location and it was superb. The staff are excellent, super accommodating and personable. It was such fun and I am definitely looking forward to returning and participating in more classes come the holidays. Thank you EQUINOX for a fit workout and a fab experience.
Stop to see a neat place. There is construction work going on on the houses around the Hitchcock house.
Historical landmark. However its a private residence and not for the public to tourists
Very unassuming - you wouldn’t know its there unless you look closely - it’s currently going through renovations so scaffolding is all over and you can just about see the plaque.
Alfred Hitchcock lived here until 1939. This is not a public building, now it's a private residence.
Alfred Bugra Home

At this address a prolific Wilde wrote his most enduring work enjoying his greatest public renown. 
Sustained by a coterie of admirers, sybarites and sycophants in a Bohemian enclave amidst a thriving artistic community. 
And from here meet his nemesis, Reading Gaol and exile. 
“Everything in moderation, including moderation.” Oscar Wilde.

My favourite play 'The Importance of Being Ernest' and a great book (and movie) 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' are product of this great man so a blue plaque in this property is a good way to celebrate his life.

A wonderful church next door to the Victoria and Albert museum.

Multiple services daily 
Confessions available daily
The pastoral team and care to parishioners is second to none.
The choir is wonderful
The church is open to all 
It truly feels like a sacred place

Beautiful church, absolutely stunning. Always like when in London to try to get to Brompton Oratory to lit candles and say prayers. 
Definitely worth a visit no matter what your faith just for the architecture

A beautiful and ornate church with lots of little aspects to explore. We popped in on our way to the Science Museum and we will be popping again next time we are in South Kensington. A very peaceful break in a hectic day and the little one surprisingly enjoyed it a lot too.

Grade II Listed Baroque church, one of 3 oratories in Britain, a formidable and imposing presence. 
A resplendent interior dressed with marble, ornate plaster, wood, metal work and rich in accoutrements.
I must confess, 
inspiring and quite magnificent
in devotional ornamentation 
Home to a renowned choir, choral school and library.
Place where you can say your prayers and have some good advice from the parish priests.

The 1958 rebuild on original footprint with a small garden surround and exterior that's, well.. notably unremarkable 
Here it's all about the reconstructed historic interior.
A meticulous and painstaking restoration of the original salvaged tombs, memorials and remnant fabric including some C16 stained glass panels. 
Quite remarkable but perhaps of more interest to ecclesiastical enthusiasts. 
The Hans Sloane memorial in the backyard featuring entwined Pythons and a colossal egg merits a peek.
An active community here.

Located in Old Church road in Chelsea Embankment.
This Church used to be the Parish Church of the Chelsea Village  before it was part of London. The building, as it stood before the war, consisted of the Chancel, dating probably from the 13th century, with Chapels on the North and South (about 1325), and the Nave and Tower (1670). The cupola was removed in 1815, but the weather vane remains.

Both Chapels were private property, that on the North, now known as the Lawrence Chapel, belonging to the Lord of the Manor of Chelsea. The present arch leading from the Chancel is a reproduction of the original 14th century one, which collapsed in 1784 and was only partly restored.

#Chelsea #Chelsea_Old_Church
This church is built on land once owned by St Thomas More, there is a statue of him outside.  There is a very small rather dark chapel in which More's wife is buried.
Beautiful Church run by Canon Reindorp who hosted my Father's funeral.  Couldn't have been better
Elizabeth 1st visited here. Despite being bombed in the 2nd ww it retains many interesting features. Worth a visit.

This church was built more than 150 years ago and hence has historical significance. Even though it is situated at a crowded junction, you can feel the peace once you walk down the path from the entrance to the church. On stepping into it you get to see a glimpse of an era that has been preserved. The peaceful and holy atmosphere is most evident in the afternoon which was the time I chose to visit it.

Right at the heart of the city, this church is a perfect location for worship. Tree covered campus, ample parking space, neatly maintained gardens and buildings. Church is pretty old, still with the old chairs and benches, same old walls and floor. Under renovation now, a new look is expected.

Resting place for the traffic police men while they're not very busy, a breathing space for them.

It was built in 1851, for the British Regiment stationed in Bangalore. 
Built in the English Renaissance style, the church can accommodate 
700 people and is regarded as the largest "military" church in southern India. 
It has a congregation of over 450 families
The church was consecrated on 25 July 1852 and opened on 8 August, 1852. 
The original estimate of the construction was ₹27,000 (US$380)
After Independence, the church was taken over by the Christian Indian Military personnel 
and their families. It was called Holy Trinity Garrison Pastorate then.
The walls were lined with ornate marble murals and tablets, which spoke about 
great men and women who toiled for the church. They Used to conduct many programs for youth especially Troika. They have a best team for youth. On March 10th they conducted the Peace Rally for the Pulwama Terrorist Attack. Really its a good experience for me. I Love this Church

When I moved to Bangalore, my fiancé was going here so he took me here. It was away from where we stay so we started checking other Tamil places nearby but now we are regularly going there. It’s worth traveling there. Best place to worship, such a nice priest. They have a good worshipping culture. You can feel Almighty’s presence there. #myfavchurch
Always a church with deep history and architecture gives a nostalgic feeling. This Tamil church surely is one of the churches which makes me feel at home and gives me a blessed experience.

A fascinating and attractive cemetery with a nice coffee shop. I love running in here and looking at the gravestones. The trees and birds are lovely. Dog owners ought to be more responsible though and something more ought to be done about loitering.

I got locked into the cemetery and loved it! Just call the fire brigade if you can't scale 4m high walls ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
May I suggest to the Royal Parks organisation who run it to maybe put a slightly bigger opening hours sign up, and install a one-way-exit door, and don't advertise an emergency/out of hours phone number if you're not going to pick up... Cos there were 3 groups of people locked in on the same summer evening.

The most beautiful and peaceful cemetery I have ever seen. You can spend hours just strolling around the cemetery which is a perfect place for photography or reading, or just taking some time to be by yourself. 

Went there by myself during a very beautiful and sunny day and felt completely safe.

The cemetery itself is lovely, but the staff are unhelpful and the Park Manager is openly rude and obnoxious. I got married locally and, having lived in the area for many years, thought it would be perfect to have some of our wedding photos taken in the grounds of the cemetery. Having submitted a 'Lifestyle Photography Application Form' I waited a week before telephoning to chase up my request, and found out that the staff were 'checking for availability' despite the fact I made it clear we needed only one hour in Mid-December for a photographer to take shots of just the bride and groom.
